11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse. 718-681-6000;
bronxmuseum.org.

BRONX The New York Botanical Garden ''Frida Kahlo: Art, Garden, Life,''
paintings, works on paper and a garden. Through Nov. 1. $10 to $25; children
under 2, free. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The New York
Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard. 718-817-8700; nybg.org.

COLD SPRING Buster Levi Gallery Works by Grace Knowlton, Barbara Smith Gioia and
Maria Pia Marrella. Through Aug. 30. Fridays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.;
and by appointment. Buster Levi Gallery, 121 Main Street. 845-809-5810;
busterlevigallery.com.

COLD SPRING Gallery 66NY ''Francesco Mastalia: Organic'' and ''Wilfredo Morel:
Farm Art.'' Through Aug. 30. ''Passing Storms'' and ''The Evolution of Shape,''
works by Rick Thurston, Gregory Martin, Cindy Booth and Carol Flaitz. Sept. 4
through 27. Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; and by appointment.
Gallery 66NY, 66 Main Street. 845-809-5838; gallery66ny.com.

GARRISON Manitoga/The Russel Wright Design Center House, studio and landscape
tours. Through Nov. 9. $10 to $20. Manitoga/The Russel Wright Design Center, 584
Route 9D. 845-424-3812; russelwrightcenter.org.

GARRISON Saunders Farm ''Collaborative Concepts: Farm Project 2015,'' group
sculpture show on a working farm. Sept. 5 through Oct. 31. Daily, 10 a.m. to
dusk. Saunders Farm, 853 Old Albany Post Road. collaborativeconcepts.org;
845-528-1797.

GHENT Omi International Arts Center ''The Crayon Miscellany,'' group show.
Through Sept. 27. Daily, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Omi International Arts Center, 1405
County Route 22. 518-392-4747; artomi.org.

GREENBURGH Madeleine Gutman Gallery ''Captivation Through Visual Inspiration,''
photographs by Monica Marrow. Through Sept. 15. Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m.
to 5 p.m. Madeleine Gutman Gallery, 177 Hillside Avenue. 914-682-1574;
greenburghartsandculture.org;

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON Upstream Gallery ''Points of View From the Circle,'' Red
Circle Photo Arts Collective. Through Aug. 30. Thursdays through Sundays, 12:30
to 5:30 p.m. Upstream Gallery, 8 Main Street. upstreamgallery.com; 914-674-8548.

HUDSON 510 Warren Street Gallery ''Sea, Sky and Shore,'' paintings by Eleanor
Lord. Through Aug. 30. ''Road Less Traveled,'' landscapes by Doris Simon. Sept.
4 through 27. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. 510
Warren Street Gallery, 510 Warren Street. 510warrenstgallery.com; 518-822-0510.

HUDSON BCB Art ''The M. Van Dyke Group: Monoprints of the 1980s.'' Through Sept.
13. Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; and by appointment. BCB Art, 116
Warren Street. 518-828-4539; bcbart.com.

HUDSON Carrie Haddad Gallery ''Paper,'' group show. Through Oct. 4. Mondays
through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Carrie Haddad
Gallery, 622 Warren Street. 518-828-1915; carriehaddadgallery.com.

HUDSON Jeff Bailey Gallery ''Joshua Marsh: Drawings'' and ''Michael Berryhill:
Shrine Time.'' Through Aug. 30. Fridays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; and by
appointment. Jeff Bailey Gallery, 127 Warren Street. baileygallery.com;
518-828-6680.

HUDSON John Davis Gallery Works by William Ransom. Through Sept. 13. Thursdays
through Mondays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; and by appointment. John Davis Gallery, 362
1/2 Warren Street. 518-828-5907; johndavisgallery.com.

HYDE PARK The Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum ''The Spirit
of the Gift: Gifts of State and Affection.'' Through Dec. 31. $6 and $9;
children under 15, free. Daily, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. through Oct. 31. The Franklin
D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum, 4079 Albany Post Road.
845-486-7745; fdrlibrary.marist.edu.

KATONAH Katonah Museum of Art ''Emilie Clark: The Delicacy of Decomposition.''
Through Sept. 6. ''Inside the Outside: Five Self-Taught Artists From the William
Louis-Dreyfus Foundation.'' ''Barnes Private Residence, 1952, Relocated, 2015.''
Through Oct. 11. $5 and $10; members and children under 12, free. Tuesdays
through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Katonah Museum of
Art, 134 Jay Street. katonahmuseum.org; 914-232-9555.

KINGSTON One Mile Gallery Works by Mary Hattman. Sept. 5 through 26. Saturdays,
noon to 5 p.m.; and by appointment. One Mile Gallery, 475 Abeel Street.
845-338-2035; onemilegallery.com.

LARCHMONT Kenise Barnes Fine Art ''Cool and Collected '15,'' group show. Through
Sept. 10. Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; and by appointment.
Kenise Barnes Fine Art, 1947 Palmer Avenue. 914-834-8077; kbfa.com.

LARCHMONT Mamaroneck Artists Guild ''Windows Doors Walls Fences,'' sumi ink
paintings by Jim Maciel. Sept. 1 through 26. Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to
5 p.m.; and by appointment. Mamaroneck Artists Guild, 126 Larchmont Avenue.
mamaroneckartistsguild.org; 914-834-1117.

MAHOPAC A. Eric Arctander Gallery, Putnam Arts Council ''Works on Paper,'' group
show. Through Aug. 30. Mondays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays
and Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. A. Eric Arctander Gallery, Putnam Arts Council, 521
Kennicut Hill Road. 845-803-8594; putnamartscouncil.com.

MAMARONECK Bullseye New York Gallery ''Dark Ecologies,'' group show. Through
Nov. 14. Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5
p.m. Bullseye New York Gallery, 115 Hoyt Avenue. bullseyeglass.com;
914-835-3794.

MOUNTAINVILLE Storm King Art Center ''Lynda Benglis: Water Sources,''
large-scale sculptures. Through Nov. 8. ''Outlooks: Luke Stettner,''
site-specific outdoor installation. Through Nov. 29. $8 to $12; members and
children under 5, free. Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Storm
King Art Center, Old Pleasant Hill Road. 845-534-3115; stormkingartcenter.org.

NEW PALTZ Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art, at the State University of New York at
New Paltz ''The Stories We Tell: Hudson Valley Artists 2015,'' group show.
Through Nov. 8. ''Jervis McEntee: Painter-Poet of the Hudson River School.''
''Reading Objects 2015,'' selections from the permanent collection. ''Thomas
Benjamin Pope: Landscapes of Newburgh and Beyond.'' Through Dec. 13. Suggested
donation, $5. Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Samuel Dorsky Museum
of Art, at the State University of New York at New Paltz, 1 Hawk Drive.
newpaltz.edu/museum; 845-257-3844.

NYACK Edward Hopper House Art Center ''Behind Doors and Through Windows:
Reflections on Contemporary Domestic Life,'' group show. Through Oct. 18. $2 to
$7; members and children under 16, free. Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5
p.m.; and by appointment. Edward Hopper House Art Center, 82 North Broadway.
edwardhopperhouse.org; 845-358-0774.

OLANA Olana State Historic Site ''River Crossings: Contemporary Art Comes
Home,'' group show. Also on display at the Thomas Cole National Historic Site in
Catskill. Through Nov. 1. $10 and $12; children under 12, free. Children under
16 admitted free at Thomas Cole. Olana State Historic Site, 5720 State Route 9G.
rivercrossings.org.

OSSINING Ossining Public Library Photographs by Anastasia Tompkins. Sept. 1
through 29. Monday and Thursday, 9 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Tuesdays and Fridays, 10 a.m.
to 6 p.m.; Wednesdays, 1 to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Ossining Public
Library, 53 Croton Avenue. 914-941-2416; ossininglibrary.org.

PEEKSKILL Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art ''Love: The First of the 7
Virtues,'' group show. ''Leviticus,'' installation by Hermann Nitsch. Through
Dec. 6. $2 to $5; members and children under 8, free. Fridays, 11 a.m. to 5
p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; and by appointment. Hudson Valley
Center for Contemporary Art, 1701 Main Street. 914-788-0100; hvcca.org.

PELHAM Pelham Art Center ''Knit Knit Bomb Bomb,'' outdoor yarn installation.
Through Aug. 31. ''The Only Home We Have,'' group show. Sept. 11 through Oct.
24. Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.
Pelham Art Center, 155 Fifth Avenue. 914-738-2525; pelhamartcenter.org.

PORT CHESTER Clay Art Center ''There's No Such Thing as the Future,'' Kelley
Donahue. Through Sept. 10. ''Tristate of Mind,'' group show. Through Sept. 16.
Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; and by appointment. Clay Art
Center, 40 Beech Street. 914-937-2047; clayartcenter.org.

McKnight. Sept. 5 through 26. Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:30
p.m.; Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturdays, 10
a.m. to 4 p.m. Duck Pond Gallery, at Town of Esopus Library, 128 Canal Street.
845-338-5580; esopuslibrary.org.

POUGHKEEPSIE The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge ''Bridge Music,''
sound installation by Joseph Bertolozzi. Through Oct. 31. Dawn to dusk. The
Franklin Delano Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge, josephbertolozzi.com.

The Prints and Multiples of Richard Artschwager.'' Through Sept. 6. Tuesdays,
Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 9
p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Vassar College, Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center, 124
Raymond Avenue. 845-437-5632; fllac.vassar.edu.

POUND RIDGE Pound Ridge Public Library ''SheilArt,'' works by Sheila Mancini.

Fridays and Saturdays; 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Pound Ridge
Public Library, 271 Westchester Avenue. poundridgelibrary.org; 914-764-5085.

PURCHASE Neuberger Museum of Art of Purchase College ''Gold,'' group show.

p.m. Neuberger Museum of Art of Purchase College, 735 Anderson Hill Road.
914-251-6100; www.neuberger.org.

and by appointment. Tivoli Artists Gallery, 60 Broadway.
tivoliartistsgallery.com; 845-757-2667.

20. Fridays, 5 to 7 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 7 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. The
Wassaic Project, Maxon Mills, 37 Furnace Bank Road. wassaicproject.org;
347-815-0783.

WHITE PLAINS ArtsWestchester ''Vision 2015: Inspirations, Reflections and
Hope,'' group show. Sept. 10 through 17, noon to 5 p.m. Tuesdays through
Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 6 p.m. ArtsWestchester, 31
Mamaroneck Avenue. artswestchester.org; 914-428-4220.

$3 to $6; members, free. Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Hudson River

Long Island

SECTION: Section LI; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; CALENDAR; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 3054 words


A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the
calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com

Comedy

SAG HARBOR Bay Street Theater All-Star Comedy Show, hosted by Joseph Vecsey.
Sept. 11 at 8 p.m. $25. Bay Street Theater, Main and Bay Streets. baystreet.org;
631-725-9500.

Film

HUNTINGTON Cinema Arts Center ''School of Babel'' (2013), directed by Julie
Bertuccelli. Sept. 1 at 7:30 p.m. $5 to $12. National Theater Live presents
''The Beaux' Stratagem,'' comedy by George Farquhar. Sept. 3 at 2 p.m. $20 and
$25. Cinema Arts Center, 423 Park Avenue. cinemaartscentre.org; 631-423-7611.

PATCHOGUE The Plaza Cinema and Media Arts Center ''King Lear, Stage in Cinema,''
film of the Shakespeare tragedy performed at the Stratford Festival in England.
Sept. 5, 10:30 a.m.; Sept 10, 6:30 p.m. $15; $12, students; $11, members. The
Plaza Cinema and Media Arts Center, 20 Terry Street. plazamac.org; 631-438-0083.

ROSLYN HARBOR Nassau County Museum of Art ''Edgar Degas: Of Dandies, Ballerinas,
and Women Ironing,'' half-hour documentary. Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m.,
noon, 1 p.m. and 3 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. and noon. Through Nov. 8. Nassau
County Museum of Art, 1 Museum Drive. nassaumuseum.org; 516-484-9337.

SOUTHAMPTON Southampton Cultural Center Southampton Jewish Film Festival.
Sundays through Sept. 6 at 7:30 p.m. $15. Southampton Cultural Center, 25 Pond
Lane. 631-287-4377; scc-arts.org.

For Children

GARDEN CITY Long Island Children's Museum ''Autumn Apple Trees,'' create a
miniature tree. Sept. 1 through 4, 2:30 to 4 p.m. Free with museum admission,
$11 and $12. Long Island Children's Museum, 11 Davis Avenue. 516-224-5800;
licm.org.

SYOSSET Syosset Public Library Exhibition of children's illustrations by Deborah
Cuneo. Sept. 4 through 27. Syosset Public Library, 225 South Oyster Bay Road.
516-921-7161; syossetlibrary.org.

Music and Dance

EAST HAMPTON Guild Hall Spin Doctors, rock. Sept. 5 at 8 p.m. $38 to $150. The
Hit Men, with former members of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons. Sept. 6 at 7
and 9:30 p.m. $38 to $75. Guild Hall, 158 Main Street. 631-324-4050;
guildhall.org.

EAST MEADOW Holy Trinity Orthodox Church Summer Festival, live Slavic music by
Barynya; bouncy castles and children's games Chinese auction; flea market and
more. Sept. 5, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Holy Trinity Orthodox Church, 369 Green Avenue.
htocem.org; 516-483-3649.

FREEPORT Freeport High School The Boys & Girls Choir of Harlem Alumni Ensemble,
directed by Anthony Morgan. Sept. 5, 8 to 10 p.m. $20. Freeport High School, 50
South Brookside Avenue. freeportconcertassociation.com; 516-223-7659.

GARDEN CITY Adelphi University Performing Arts Center ''Baths of Caracalla: The
Three Tenors Concert,'' concert film of Luciano Pavarotti, PlácidoDomingo and
José Carreras in 1990. Sept. 12 at 2 p.m. $20. Adelphi University Performing
Arts Center, 1 South Avenue. aupac.adelphi.edu; 516-877-4000.

HEMPSTEAD Guthart Cultural Center Theater, Joan and Donald E. Axinn Library
''Feis Dress: The History of Irish Dance Costumes,'' Hofstra University's Irish
Studies Department. Sept. 10, 6 to 7:30 p.m. Free. Guthart Cultural Center
Theater, Joan and Donald E. Axinn Library, Hofstra University, South Campus.
hofstra.edu; 516-463-6644.

HUNTINGTON The Paramount ''Catch a Fire Tour 2015,'' reggae, Damian Marley,
Stephen Marley, Morgan Heritage, Tarrus Riley and others. Sept. 1 at 8 p.m. $30
to $45. The Jacksons, R&B. Sept. 3 at 8 p.m. $25 to $89.50. Billy Bob Thorton
and the Boxmasters, country rock. Sept. 6 at 8 p.m. $25 to $50. ''Donny Osmond:
The Soundtrack of My Life Tour,'' pop. Sept. 10 at 8 p.m. $59.50 to $119.50. The
Paramount, 370 New York Avenue. 631-673-7300; paramountny.com.

LONG BEACH Long Beach Public Library ''Stan Wiest Piano Concert and Great
American Songbook Singalong,'' Stan Wiest plays the piano, tells anecdotes and
leads a singalong. Sept. 13, 1:30 to 3 p.m. Free. Long Beach Public Library, 111
West Park Avenue. 516-432-7201; nassaulibrary.org/longbeach.

PORT WASHINGTON Landmark on Main Street Warren Schein performs ''The American
Songbook.'' Sept. 9 at 2 p.m. Free. Landmark on Main Street, 232 Main Street.
516-767-6444; landmarkonmainstreet.org.

QUOGUE Hampton Theater Company, Quogue Community Hall Quogue Chamber Music,
Cavani String Quartet and the clarinetist Daniel Gilbert, works by Mozart,
Dvorak and Debussy. Sept. 12 at 7:30 p.m. $5 and $40. Hampton Theater Company,
Quogue Community Hall, 125 Jessup Avenue. 631-728-3407; quoguechambermusic.com.

ROSLYN HARBOR Nassau County Museum of Art Joe Dubs and the Jazz Connection,
museum's house band. Aug. 30 at 3 p.m. Free with museum admission, $4 to $10.
Nassau County Museum of Art, 1 Museum Drive. nassaumuseum.org; 516-484-9337.
SOUTHAMPTON Southampton Cultural Center ''It's A Good Day: A Tribute to Ms.
Peggy Lee,'' cabaret with Stacy Sullivan. Sept. 12 at 7 p.m. $35 to $45.
Southampton Cultural Center, 25 Pond Lane. 631- 287-4377; scc-arts.org.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center The Bronx Wanderers,
rock. Aug. 30 at 8 p.m. $33 and $53. Keb' Mo', blues. Sept. 4 at 8 p.m. $73 to
$103. John Hiatt, rock. Sept. 6 at 8 p.m. $60 to $100. Westhampton Beach
Performing Arts Center, 76 Main Street. 631-288-1500; whbpac.org.

Outdoors

EAST MEADOW Eisenhower Park Fourth Annual Children's Walk Against Brain Tumors
and Brain Cancer, sponsored by Children's Brain Tumor Foundation. Sept. 13 at 10
a.m. $10. Eisenhower Park, 1899 Hempstead Turnpike. 212-448-9494;
firstgiving.com.

HUNTINGTON Heckscher Park Kiss Cancer Goodbye Walk, fund-raising event for Kids
Need More, which helps children and families coping with life-threatening
illnesses. Sept. 12, 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. $20; includes T-shirt. Heckscher Park, 64
Main Street, corner 24A and Prime Avenue. drgellerman.com; 631-427-8444.

ROSLYN HARBOR Nassau County Museum of Art ''Bird Watching for Beginners,''
Rebecca Oyer of the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary and Audubon Center leads an
observation of birds on the museum property. Sept. 9 at 9 a.m. $10; reservations
required. Nassau County Museum of Art, 1 Museum Drive. 516-484-9337;
nassaumuseum.org.

Spoken Word

HUNTINGTON Library at Seminary of the Immaculate Conception Elizabeth Scalia,
author and blogger, discussing her book ''Strange Gods: Unmasking the Idols in
Everyday Life.'' Sept. 13 at 2 p.m. Free. Library at Seminary of the Immaculate
Conception, 440 West Neck Road. icseminary.edu/library; 631-423-0483, ext. 141.

LAWRENCE Peninsula Public Library ''Culture & Continuity: The Jewish Museum,''
illustrated lecture focused on works by Marc Chagall, Thomas Sully, James Tissot
and others. Sept. 3 at 1 p.m. Free. Peninsula Public Library, 280 Central
Avenue. nassaulibrary.org/peninsula; 516-239-3262.

Theater

BELLPORT Gateway Playhouse ''Saturday Night Fever,'' musical. Through Sept. 12.
$54 to $89. Gateway Playhouse, 215 South Country Road. gatewayplayhouse.com;
631-286-1133.

LINDENHURST Studio Theater ''Lie of Omission,'' drama by Cheryl Navo. Sept. 4
through 20. $25. Studio Theater, 141 South Wellwood Avenue. 631-226-8400;
studiotheatreli.com.

NORTHPORT John W. Engeman Theater at Northport ''The Cottage,'' comedy by Sandy
Rustin. Through Sept. 6. $59 and $64. John W. Engeman Theater at Northport, 250
Main Street. 631-261-2900; engemantheater.com.

SAG HARBOR Bay Street Theater ''Grey Gardens,'' musical with book by Doug
Wright, music by Scott Frankel and lyrics by Michael Korie. Through Aug. 30.
$62.55 to $85. Bay Street Theater, Main and Bay Streets. baystreet.org;
631-725-9500.

SMITHTOWN Smithtown Center for the Performing Arts ''West Side Story,'' musical
by Leonard Bernstein, Stephen Sondheim and Arthur Laurents. Through Aug. 30.
$35. ''Arsenic and Old Lace,'' by Joseph Kesserling. Sept. 12 through Oct. 4.
$35. Smithtown Center for the Performing Arts, 2 East Main Street. 631-724-3700;
smithtownpac.org.

Museums and Galleries

BELLPORT Gallery 125 ''Arthur Pinajian (1914-1999), a Survey Exhibition.''
Through Sept. 6. Fridays, 4 to 7 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Gallery 125,
125 South Country Road. gallery125.org; 631-880-2693.

BRIDGEHAMPTON Silas Marder Gallery Recent work by Mica Marder, including
drawings, paintings and sculpture. Sept. 5 through Oct. 17. Reception: Sept. 5,
4 to 8 p.m. Thursdays through Mondays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Silas Marder Gallery,
120 Snake Hollow Road. 631-702-2306; silasmarder.com.

BRIDGEHAMPTON The Design Studio ''Upcycle,'' artwork from recycled materials.
Through Sept. 15. Mondays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays and
Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. The Design Studio,
2393 Main Street. elisacontemporaryart.com.

COLD SPRING HARBOR Cold Spring Harbor Whaling Museum ''Sea Ink: American Sailors
and Tattoo Art,'' antique tattoo machines, inking tools and information about
the origins of nautical tattoos. Through Aug. 31. $5 to $6; members and children
under 5, free. Daily, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Cold Spring Harbor Whaling Museum, 301
Main Street. cshwhalingmuseum.org; 631-367-3418.

CUTCHOGUE Alex Ferrone Photography Gallery ''Calm Before the Storm,''
photographic works by Christine Matthäi. Sept. 5 through 27. Alex Ferrone
Photography Gallery, 25425 Main Road. 631-734-8545; alexferrone.com.

EAST HAMPTON Eric Firestone Gallery ''All Killer No Filler,'' works by 11
artists. Through Sept. 6. Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays
and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Eric Firestone Gallery, 4 Newtown Lane.
631-604-2386; ericfirestonegallery.com.

EAST HAMPTON Guild Hall ''Roy Lichtenstein: Between Sea and Sky,'' contemporary
works. Through Oct. 12. Suggested donation: $7. Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m.
to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Guild Hall, 158 Main Street. 631-324-4050;
guildhall.org.

EAST HAMPTON Haute Hippie East Hampton ''Summertime Salon,'' group show. Through
Sept. 6. Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to Saturdays,
10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Haute Hippie East Hampton, 20 Newtown Lane. 212-239-6825.

EAST ISLIP Islip Art Museum ''IAM Pocket Sized,'' group show. Through Sept. 13.
Suggested donation, $5. Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.;
Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Islip Art Museum, 50 Irish Lane. 631-224-5402;
islipartmuseum.org.

GARDEN CITY  Ruth S. Harley University Center Gallery, Adelphi University
Paintings by Richmond Lewis. Through Sept. 22. Reception, Sept. 15, 5 to 7 p.m.
Mondays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5
p.m. Ruth S. Harley University Center Gallery, Adelphi University, 1 South
Avenue. 516-877-3126; adelphi.edu/artmuseum.

GLEN COVE Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center ''Scenes of Horror: A Photo
History of the Armenian Genocide,'' film, text and photos. Through Sept. 30.
Suggested donation, $10. Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.;
Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, noon to 4 p.m. Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance

Irina Lisker, Michael Weil

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 134 words


Dr. Irina Lisker and Michael Joseph Weil are to be married Sunday by Rabbi
Ronald Roth at the Estate at the Florentine Gardens, a party space in River
Vale, N.J.

The bride, 32, is a second-year resident in family medicine at Hunterdon Medical
Center in Flemington, N.J. She graduated cum laude from Mount Holyoke and
received a medical degree from the University of Connecticut. She is a daughter
of Isabella E. Lisker of New London, Conn.

The groom, 30, is a law clerk to Judge Anthony F. Picheca of the New Jersey
Superior Court, who has his chambers in Somerville, N.J. He graduated magna cum
laude from George Washington and received a law degree with high honors from
UConn. He is a son of Bena H. Weil and Steven K. Weil of Fair Lawn, N.J.

The couple were introduced through the dating site JDate.

Playoff-Bound Liberty Collect 20th Win

BYLINE: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Section SP; Column 0; Sports Desk; LIBERTY 80, SUN 66; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 131 words


UNCASVILLE, Conn. --  Epiphanny Prince had 18 points and 4 steals, and Tina
Charles added 15 points and 5 assists to help the Liberty beat the Connecticut
Sun, 80-66, on Saturday night.

The Liberty (20-8) had already clinched their first playoff berth since 2012
with an 81-68 home victory over the Minnesota Lynx at Madison Square Garden on
Friday night.

Kiah Stokes had 12 points and 10 rebounds, Swin Cash finished with 11 points,
and the Liberty outscored the Sun by 23-9 in the fourth quarter.

A Cash 3-pointer gave the Liberty a 64-61 lead with 7 minutes 15 seconds left.
They closed the game on a 16-5 run.

The Liberty shot a season-high 55.9 percent (33 of 59) from the field.

Kelsey Bone led the Sun (12-17) with 22 points and 7 rebounds.

The Sun have lost seven straight.

Jacquelyn Leung, Marshall Ford

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 233 words


Jacquelyn Frances Leung, the daughter of Alice Leung and Andrew Leung of Boonton
Township, N.J., was married Monday to Marshall Thomas Ford, the son of Merrie M.
Ford and Tim R. Ford of Kansas City, Mo. Michael McSweeney, the New York City
clerk, officiated at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.

On Saturday, the Rev. Donald Wong, who was ordained by the Church of Living
Grace, led a nondenominational Christian ceremony at Maritime Parc, an events
space in Jersey City.

Mrs. Ford, 28, is an occupational therapist working with older adults at Fox
Rehabilitation in New York. She graduated from Boston University, from which she
also received a master's in occupational therapy.

Her father is the executive vice president and the principal engineer of YU &
Associates, a consulting engineering firm in Elmwood Park, N.J. Her mother is a
finance manager in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., for Eisai, a Japanese pharmaceutical
company.

Mr. Ford, also 28, is a customer performance analyst in New York for the AmeriCo
Group, providing analysis of retail data. He graduated from the University of
Denver and received a master's degree in international management from Portland
State University.

His mother is the administrative assistant in Kansas City for Valorem
Consulting. His father is an international business coach for SkillPath, a
company in Mission, Kan., that provides professional development training.

Letters

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 967 words


L.A. Laws

To the Editor:

In his review of ''Blue: The LAPD and the Battle to Redeem American Policing''
(Aug. 9), Mark Horowitz omitted two political developments that were crucial to
William Bratton's appointment as chief of the Los Angeles Police Department.

The first were amendments to the city's charter imposing a two-term limit on the
police chief's tenure and expanding the mayor's authority by assigning to him or
her the power to appoint the chief. The second was the political courage of
James K. Hahn, the first mayor to take office under the new rules.

Hahn, who is white, was heavily dependent on the African-American vote when he
was elected mayor. Bernard Parks, the incumbent chief, who is black, was
immensely popular in the African-American community despite his well-known
reputation for opposing meaningful reform. Hahn knew his support in that
community would plummet if he refused to reappoint Parks. Yet he also knew from
his years as city attorney how firmly the old- school Parks was opposed to the
substantive changes Hahn had come to believe were essential to reforming the
department.

Hahn doomed his own re-Â­election when he refused to reappoint Parks and
appointed Bratton, and the entire city has been better off for it ever since.

DAVID I. SCHULMAN

LOS ANGELES

The writer was a Los Angeles deputy city attorney from 1980 to 2012.

â¬¥

Marian Evans, Saloniste

To the Editor:

''Marian Evans .â[#x20ac][#x2c6].â[#x20ac][#x2c6]. scandalously cohabiting with
a married man .â[#x20ac][#x2c6].â[#x20ac][#x2c6]. was a social pariah,'' Jo
Baker writes in her review of ''Sophie and the Sybil'' (Aug. 16). ''But Eliot
was now a success.''

The unpublished guest lists kept by George Henry Lewes (available at the Yale
University Library), who noted each arrival at the Sunday salon he and George
Eliot conducted from 1869 to 1878 (see my book ''George Eliot in Society:
Travels Abroad and Sundays at the Priory''), reveal that Evans/Eliot did not
remain a ''pariah'' for long after her illegal union with Lewes. Her salon
welcomed many notable Victorians (Robert Browning, Charles Darwin, Herbert
Spencer, George du Maurier), including many women (Edith Simcox, Rosalind
Howard, Barbara Bodichon, Lady Castletown). Although some of the most faithful
male visitors (notably Anthony Trollope) did not bring their wives to the
Priory, the word pariah does not apply to the woman who conducted well-attended
Victorian Sunday salons until Lewes's death in 1878.

KATHLEEN McCORMACK

NORTH MIAMI, FLA.

The writer is a professor of literature at Florida International University.

â¬¥

Whose ClichÃ©?

To the Editor:

I appreciate Kyla Wazana Tompkins's review of my novel ''Lincoln's Billy''
(Shortlist, Aug. 16), about William Herndon. But when she concludes by calling
out a ''genre clichÃ©'' and quotes the phrase ''vigorous and comely mulatto''
from the novel, the danger of writing researched historical fiction became clear
to me.

Lincoln's cousin John Hanks used that phrase when he described Lincoln's
witnessing a slave auction in New Orleans as a youth, reputedly the origin of
the future president's disgust with slavery. Herndon, in his 1889 biography of
Lincoln, quoted Hanks, and I made that clear in the novel: I was quoting Herndon
quoting Hanks. My point: I am twice removed from the clichÃ© of the comely
mulatto.

The irony is that Hanks wasn't even in New Orleans, where he supposedly saw
Lincoln respond to the auction. Perhaps the unreliable Hanks was falling back on
a ''genre clichÃ©'' when he told his story.

TOM LeCLAIR

BROOKLYN

â¬¥

Murakami and Bellow

To the Editor:

There is little question that many of Haruki Murakami's novels display the
influence of Kafka, as Steve Erickson observes in his review of ''Wind/Pinball''
(Aug. 16). He also notes Murakami's references to Henry James, President
Kennedy, Glenn Gould, Marvin Gaye and the Mickey Mouse Club, among others.

That's quite a diverse lineup, but missing from the list was someone whose
technique I have found in many of Murakami's works -- Saul Bellow. Advancing
plot and character development through the use of intense, deeply philosophical
one-on-one conversations between characters is a Bellovian touch that serves
Murakami well.

JOHN F. HOGAN

CHICAGO

â¬¥

That Time

To the Editor:

In her Critic's Take essay (''It's the End of the World as She Knows It,'' July
26), Sloane Crosley parenthetically notes that ''plenty of plots in
post-apocalyptic fiction have to do with pregnancy, but, as far as I know, no
one in the history of the genre ever has her period.''

I agree that menstruating females are a rarity in dystopian and post-apocalyptic
fiction. Who has time, while depicting survivors collecting canned goods and
seeking shelter from roving cannibals, to portray desperate women seeking out
the remaining stores of Advil, tampons and bourbon?

But in Chapter 4 of George Orwell's ''1984,'' Julia, Winston Smith's lover in
the Outer Party, gets her period. They are meeting in secret, and she cancels a
planned tryst because of ''the usual reason. It's started early this time.''
This initially frustrates Smith, but it does provoke him to ponder what life
would be like if negotiating sex around Julia's cycle were the only thing
affecting their sexual lives, as opposed to also having to deal with his
varicose ulcer, their vastly reduced resources and all that police state stuff.

I also think you're more likely to see a menstruating female in a dystopia,
paradoxically, when the characters are not interested in repopulation: when the
proles have the childbearing thing covered and sex, as it does for Winston and
Julia, largely concerns pleasure, privacy and anything else denied them in this
landscape.

LISA FLUET

BOSTON

The writer is an assistant professor of English at the College of the Holy
Cross.

Lebanese Protesters Aiming for Rare Unity Against Gridlocked Government

BYLINE: By ANNE BARNARD; Hwaida Saad contributed reporting.

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1338 words


BEIRUT, Lebanon --  Thousands of Lebanese demonstrators gathered on Saturday
evening to protest towering garbage piles, corruption and political dysfunction,
infusing new momentum into a campaign for better governance that seeks to unite
citizens often divided by religion and politics.

The crowd in downtown Beirut was the movement's biggest turnout yet, despite
earlier fears of violence. Last weekend, security forces used water cannons,
tear gas and rubber bullets, and some protesters threw rocks. But on Saturday,
activists and authorities alike vowed to avoid clashes and largely succeeded,
with some arrests of protesters after most had gone home.

As demonstrators waved Lebanese flags and danced to Arabic music, a sense of
excitement and possibility grew. Many see the movement as a rare chance to unite
Lebanon behind a cause not drummed up by any religious or political leader.
Indeed, a sentiment common among a wide spectrum of protesters is
disillusionment with the country's entire political class amid the longstanding
failure of the state to provide basic services while leaders bicker over profits
and patronage.

Gathering on Martyrs' Square -- a symbolic area between the eastern and western
districts of Beirut whose residents fought each other for much of the civil war
a generation ago -- organizers declared they were against all the political
leaders.

''Everybody means everybody,'' said Assaad Thebian, one of a small group of
organizers who started protests a month ago over the collapse of garbage
collection. They have named their movement ''You Stink.''

The protests have quickly broadened, drawing a range of environmental,
good-governance, labor and leftist groups, as well as members of the public who
say they have not been summoned by any group. Interest has grown even as many
Lebanese worry that the movement will be hijacked by political groups and try to
decode hidden agendas among the protesters.

As protesters marched downtown, they chanted, ''No to sectarianism. This is a
popular revolution.'' Some added, ''The people want the fall of the regime,'' a
typical rallying cry from the Arab revolts, or simply, ''Revolution!''

Some indicated that they had no desire to topple the entire system and that they
wanted only to press Lebanon's Parliament and cabinet to resign.

Still, it was striking to hear such cries, often in jovial tones, in 2015, more
than four years after the Arab revolts began with protests in Tunisia, Syria,
Libya and Egypt -- countries now struggling with varying degrees of violence and
disappointment.

Most central to the Lebanese experience is the war next door in Syria, which has
killed well over 200,000 people and driven millions from the country. But unlike
authoritarian Syria, Lebanon has a weak government that has long tolerated
fractious political disputes. Protesters said that even though rival Lebanese
factions back opposite sides in Syria, protests here would not lead to major
violence -- much less state collapse.

''The difference is, we don't want to bring down our structure,'' said Maria
Keserwani, 27, a human resources manager who camped out the night before with
fellow protesters from various sects. ''We want our structure to stay, but we
want it to improve.''

One of her companions, Elias Nassar, said, ''Besides, Lebanon has lived through
civil war, and we all know we don't want that.''

Others said Saturday that the demands needed to be sharpened. Nizam Abou Khzam,
a leader of the Lebanon Eco Movement, said his group wanted to stick to narrow
goals.

''We are not for toppling the regime, we are for reforms,'' he said. ''To be
effective, we have to be logical.''

But Ali, an academic in a pinstriped suit and paisley cravat who declined to
give his full name, said the mistake was in not taking enough risks.

''There should be more violence,'' he said, adding that he did not want anyone
to be hurt, but that it had been a mistake for organizers to pull back from the
streets last Sunday after rumors circulated of infiltrators instigating
violence. It was a case, he said, of bourgeois protesters mislabeling fired-up
working-class teenagers as thugs.

Ansar al-Andari, 32, drove an hour with her two young boys to attend the march,
all of them decked out in Lebanese flags. Her demands were straightforward:
''Electricity, water and dignity,'' she said. ''And get these sectarian thieves
out. We look at each other as enemies while they are filling their pockets. It's
not enough to sit home and complain.''

Nowhere to be seen were the flags of the different religious and political
factions that jockey for power in Lebanon. That absence was what lured many
first-time protesters, like Noor Abbas.

Ms. Abbas, 19, is from the southern suburbs of Beirut, where Hezbollah is
popular. She said she came when she saw that earlier protests featured ''no
politicians.'' She wore a pink head scarf; her friend wore a purple one. ''I'm
so hopeful,'' she said. ''So happy. We want to change the system.''

The main political divide in Lebanon is between the March 14 movement, which
came together to demand the end of Syria's military presence in Lebanon in 2005
after the assassination of the former prime minister Rafik Hariri, and the March
8 movement, which backed the Syrian government.

The main player of March 8 is Hezbollah, the Shiite militant group and political
party. For March 14, it is the Future Movement, Hezbollah's main Sunni rival. On
Saturday, some protesters shouted, ''14 and 8, they turned the country into a
corner shop.''

A voice from a loudspeaker said, ''One is with Saudi Arabia, one is with Iran,''
referring to the March 14 and 8 movements and their respective international
patrons.

The You Stink activists gave the government a 72-hour ultimatum to meet their
demands, or face even larger protests.

The activists called for accountability of security forces' use of violence
against protesters, including from the interior minister, Nohad Mashnouq; the
resignation of the environment minister, Mohammad Mashnouq (no relation), who
presided over the garbage crisis; the release of money owed by the government to
municipalities to handle their trash; and parliamentary elections.

Some politicians have attempted to cast blame on their rivals.

''They are trying to play the usual game,'' said Shadban Fakih, 27, a graphic
designer. ''What they don't understand is that we are against all of them.''

Political gridlock has left Lebanon without a president for more than a year,
and Parliament has extended its own mandate twice, delaying elections until
2017. The system has divided top posts among Shiites, Sunnis and Christians
since before the civil war, and it is seen as a way of ensuring power sharing.

Few are calling for that system to be scrapped wholesale any time soon. Most are
seeking instead to dismantle the system of sectarian patronage that has grown up
around it, and calling for accountability and transparency from the government.

While there were many middle-class families and white-collar professionals,
there were also people from working-class neighborhoods across Lebanon's
religious spectrum.

Among them were groups of rambunctious teenagers who had come -- respectively --
from modest Sunni and Shiite neighborhoods that lack reliable electricity and
water. Both groups complained that they could not get jobs without ''wasta,''
the word for pull or connections.

Ali Halawi, 19, who lives in the largely Shiite Dahiyeh area, said, ''Just to
get into the army, I was asked to pay a bribe.'' Instead, he said, he works
fixing toilets.

Also protesting was Mohammed, 16, from the mostly Sunni Tariq Jadideh area, who
declined to give his last name. Asked what his demands were, he said, ''I just
want to take a shower.''

Some protesters at the end tried to break through a security fence. Riot police
cleared them away and made arrests. One of Mr. Halawi's friends said they had
been beaten by the police -- and would be back on Tuesday to protest more.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/world/middleeast/lebanon-protests-garbage-gove
rnment-corruption.html

latest antigovernment protest. (PHOTOGRAPH BY MOHAMED AZAKIR/REUTERS)

Closing the Book

BYLINE: By DYLAN LANDIS.

Dylan Landis is the author of a ­novel, ''Rainey Royal,'' and a story
collection, ''Normal People Don't Live Like This.''

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; CRITIC'S TAKE; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 863 words


It didn't surprise me, when my parents were dying, that I couldn't write. But it
shocked me, as a writer of fiction, that I couldn't read.

I saw them twice a week. My father was difficult. When in the hospital, he
sundowned often -- raging against institutions where he believed he was the only
patient, subject of a sick psychiatric joke. I missed his gentle wisdom. My
mother remained a sweetheart, smiling at even the roughest nurses who came to
suction her tracheotomy tube.

When I took the train from New York City to Tarrytown, near their Sleepy Hollow
home, I expected to read as if famished. After all, in 2008, when I had commuted
two hours a day to radiation therapy for breast cancer, I had read dozens of
novels on the bus. I had been afraid -- of my body, and for my body -- and
novels transported me. This time, I found myself staring out the train windows,
book in lap, unread.

And when my parents napped, instead of curling into the guest chair to read, I
daughtered, picking up Kleenex blossoms, straightening papers and updating their
friends. I opened books, listlessly closed them and talked to the aides about
their boyfriends, their money and, with some of them, God.

Of course I wondered what was wrong with me. Normally, I would read a book or
two a week, not only for pleasure but for the sheer joy of study. Now, I read
almost solely for work, and could not sink deeply into a text.

I had begun keeping a reading list, and noticed it was a kind of EKG of the
heart and mind. Some months I read only one book -- one book. A year ago March,
with my father slumped in his wheelchair, mute, two months before his death, the
list shows that I opened two books and finished neither. I judged myself
harshly. You are a writer -- books should be your salve. But they were not.

I wanted to read as I grieved my still living, slipping-away parents. But I had
lost my way to literature as refuge and inspiration. Just as I had been reduced
to writing emails instead of my own novel chapters, I found myself reading
Facebook on the hospital Wi-Fi instead of books.

Words on paper had been reduced by grief to what painters call marks. As such,
they had lost their power to resonate. So I found myself grieving, too, what I
took to be an understandable loss of concentration.

My father died in late May, my mother seven weeks later. They left a large, deep
and disordered library, and in yet another loss, I had no room in my apartment
for more than a carton of their books.

That summer I found refuge in the beautiful gloom of Hans Fallada's ''Every Man
Dies Alone,'' but only in that. Through July and August I commuted to clean out
my parents' apartment -- or, rather, to traipse around it in a daze. For it was
I who was scoured out.

Unable to find comfort in reading, the activity that had sheltered me for years,
I began to wonder if I had brought this isolation on myself. Had I walled out
words, overcome by the emotion they evoke?

A powerful book does not so much contain emotion as elicit it in the reader, an
experience I must have found crushing. When I teach fiction, I quote Chekhov
about the need to ''be more cold'' in one's writing -- to not baldly state
emotion, but rather coolly to put down the details of a scene so the reader, in
response, can step in and experience the emotion ­for herself.

I had stripped my parents when they died, washed their bodies, dressed them for
cremation. By then, all I wanted was anesthetic, the very opposite of a book.

The list shows I kept struggling to read. In the winter months, I started 11
books. But my notations betray my lack of focus: must finish, must finish, must
finish.

Perhaps what I could not tolerate were endings.

What are you reading, friends asked, and I hedged. I named books on the night
stand, books I would never complete, or the same few books I had managed to
power through. I finally admitted this to my writing partner, Heather Sellers,
and to my deep relief she said: ''After my father died, I couldn't read for a
year. I couldn't go on that journey. I couldn't even pack for the trip.''

Finally, nine months after my mother's death, the ability to read slowly began
to return. I found I could read for about 15 minutes at a time -- a fraction of
the two-hour plunges I once took. On rare occasions, I would fall into a state
of grace and once again a book consumed me. Yet my subject matter seemed
curiously circumscribed. Long ago, biologists used to say ''ontogeny repeats
phylogeny,'' meaning fetal growth reiterates the stages of evolution. (It only
looks that way.) My newly recovered ability to dwell on words may have
reiterated the stages of my life. All I could relish, at that stage, were novels
with young female protagonists, 14-, 15-year-olds, troubled, like the girls I
write about and once identified with. ''My Brilliant Friend,'' by Elena
Ferrante. ''Sister Golden Hair,'' by Darcey Steinke. ''The Scamp,'' by Jennifer
Pashley.

I've heard it said that we don't mature fully till we lose both parents. Perhaps
I had to relive, in these novels, my early adolescence before I could start to
find that new adulthood -- and lose myself in reading again.




URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/books/review/closing-the-book.html

(90%); WRITERS (89%); NUCLEAR MEDICINE (77%); CANCER (76%); COMMUTING (74%);
RADIOLOGY (72%); ONCOLOGY (71%); TRAINS (70%); CHEMOTHERAPY & RADIATION (69%);

Secret Shame

BYLINE: By LAILA LALAMI.

Laila Lalami's most recent novel, ''The Moor's Account,'' was a finalist for the
Pulitzer Prize.

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 835 words


FLOOD OF FIREBy Amitav Ghosh 616 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $28.  To read
Amitav Ghosh's ''Flood of Fire'' is to enter a world of sepoys, sahibs and
rajahs, traveling with them from Assam to Calcutta to Canton, all the while
learning about their pasts and dreading or hoping for their futures. It is a
fictional journey both physical and temporal and, like real journeys, best
appreciated when one is willing to accept detours and adventures.

Many of the characters will be familiar to readers of the previous two volumes
of Ghosh's Ibis trilogy. In the first, ''Sea of Poppies,'' he introduced us to
Deeti, a widow who flees her husband's funeral pyre only to end up on the Ibis,
a former slave ship transporting indentured servants from India to Mauritius.
Deeti and a few others manage to escape the life that awaits them on the sugar
estates, claiming new identities. In ''River of Smoke,'' the second installment,
Ghosh moved the narrative to Canton, specifically to ­Fanqui-town, the enclave
where foreigners live and trade with the locals. At a time when the Chinese
authorities are attempting to abolish the opium trade, a Parsee merchant from
Bombay tries to make his fortune from a single, massive shipment.

Now, in ''Flood of Fire,'' the trilogy's final volume, Ghosh picks up the story
in 1839, a few months before the outbreak of the First Opium War. We meet Kesri
Singh, a sepoy -- an Indian soldier in the British service -- who has now
volunteered to be part of an expeditionary force for the East India Company;
Zachary Reid, an American sailor who quite unexpectedly finds himself in a
position to trade in opium; Shireen Modi, a widow who travels to China to look
for her late husband's illegitimate child; and Neel Rattan Halder, a rajah who
was separated from his son after his arrest by the British.

All four characters are by turns helped or thwarted in their desires by the
forces of the opium trade, forces that are essentially beyond their control. All
four also carry a secret shame. Kesri Singh has been told that his sister Deeti
deserted her husband, the brother of his own superior, and took up with a
low-caste laborer, bringing dishonor on the family. Zachary Reid, the son of an
American slave, now passes as white and hopes to enter a trade largely dominated
by white men. Shireen Modi has begun to have feelings for the Armenian man who
was her husband's close friend, a relationship that would surely be frowned upon
if the Parsee community discovered it. And Neel Rattan Halder, the former Rajah
of Raskhali, is in hiding because he has been convicted on trumped-up charges of
forgery and, if found, will be hauled off to jail.

These are the elements of the social novel -- characters held together or kept
apart by a powerful array of cultural, racial and religious norms. Inevitably,
questions of loyalty and betrayal arise, and none find easy answers. As Neel
writes in his diary, ''It is madness to think that knowing a language and
reading a few books can create allegiances between people. Thoughts, books,
ideas, words -- if anything they make you more alone, because they destroy
whatever instinctive loyalties you may once have possessed.''

Ghosh, the author of seven previous novels and five books of nonfiction, is a
writer with a passion for language. He doesn't simply create a world, he
delights in giving it the truest words. In his prose, a half-Indian,
half-Chinese opium addict sounds completely different from an upper-class Parsee
widow, who in turn sounds completely different from a British woman who has been
raised in India. (In one amusing episode, the British woman comes up with an
impressive array of terms for sex organs or sex acts. She calls a slack penis
''a sleeping bawhawder,'' masturbation is referred to as ''soaping the sepoy''
and cunnilingus becomes ''making a chutney.'')

Ghosh's novel is also concerned with how the nascent free trade of the region
has brought about a major conflict, which is resolved through military force.
Watching one of the battles of the Opium War, Neel wonders: ''How was it
possible that a small number of men, in the span of a few hours or minutes,
could decide the fate of millions of people yet unborn? How was it possible that
the outcome of those brief moments could determine who would rule whom, who
would be rich or poor, master or servant, for generations to come?''

''Flood of Fire'' is what Henry James might have called a loose, baggy monster.
The novel brims with wonderful historical details, clearly the result of
prodigious research. But at times Ghosh adds background information that, while
perhaps useful to readers unfamiliar with the earlier books in the trilogy,
weighs down the narrative. And Neel's part of the novel, told in the form of a
diary, occasionally lacks the drama and immediacy of the others. Still, Ghosh
has so much passion for his subject, so much care for his characters and such a
command of his prose that readers will find it easy to surrender to the story.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/books/review/amitav-ghoshs-flood-of-fire.html

TRAFFICKING (71%); ARRESTS (66%); MEN (64%); COUNTERFEITING (50%)

                              Late Edition - Final

This Land Is Our Land

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS KRISTOF

SECTION: Section SR; Column 0; Editorial Desk; OP-ED COLUMNIST; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 828 words


THE other day, my teenage daughter and I were idly browsing real estate porn, a
monument to American inequality: a private island in the Bahamas selling for
$17.9 million; a 900-acre retreat in Washington State for $11 million; and an
83-acre estate in Colorado for a cool $100 million.

Then we snapped out of the covetousness, for we had just been enjoying a
vacation on even more exclusive property, so valuable that no hedge fund manager
could ever afford to buy or rent it.

We had been hiking day after day past pristine mountain lakes, serenaded by the
babble of snow-fed streams, greeted by vivid wildflowers in alpine meadows. And
it's all my land!

Of course, it's also your land. It's our extraordinary national inheritance, one
of the greatest gifts of our ancestors -- our public lands.

My daughter and I were backpacking a 210-mile stretch of the Pacific Crest Trail
in central California, from Donner Pass to Yosemite. The cost? It was all free.

Most of the time in America, we're surrounded by oppressive inequality, such
that the wealthiest 1 percent collectively own substantially more than the
bottom 90 percent. One escape from that is America's wild places.

At a time when so much else in America is rationed by price, egalitarianism
thrives in the wilderness. On the trail, no one can pull rank on you -- except a
grizzly bear. (In that case, be very deferential!)

Wilderness trails constitute a rare space in America marked by economic
diversity. Lawyers and construction workers get bitten by the same mosquitoes
and sip from the same streams; there are none of the usual signals about
socioeconomic status, for most hikers are in shorts and a T-shirt, and enveloped
by an aroma that would make a skunk queasy.

The wild offers the simplest and cheapest of vacations. My daughter and I unroll
our sleeping bags on a $5 plastic sheet and watch shooting stars until we fall
asleep (if it rains we set up a tarp). We carry all our food. And at the end, we
sometimes try to hitchhike back to civilization (although drivers mostly speed
up when they see me).

Car campers often pay fees. But there are almost never fees for backpackers in
the real wilderness. Instead, you pay in sweat and blisters.

In that respect, the wilderness reflects a vision for America that is more
democratic than just about any other space in our country.

I can't help thinking that if the American West were discovered today, the most
glorious bits would be sold off to the highest bidder. Yosemite might be nothing
but weekend homes for Internet tycoons.

Fortunately, America's visionaries back then didn't think that way. People like
Theodore Roosevelt and Gifford Pinchot who helped preserve our wild places were
personally wealthy and could afford country estates. But they understood the
importance of common ownership of some of America's natural heritage, so that
access didn't depend on wealth or breeding.

Their vision reflected a deep belief at the time, among Republicans as well as
Democrats, in public services that transcended class. The result was the world's
best public school system at the time, networks of public libraries, public
parks and beaches, and later a broad system of public universities and community
colleges.

Sadly, that belief in public goods today seems old-fashioned!

My daughter and I are hiking the full Pacific Crest Trail, 2,650 miles from
Mexico to Canada, in the narrow window in which she's strong enough and I'm not
yet decrepit. We've hiked half and hope to finish in another five or six years.

My favorite area this time was the area south of Sonora Pass, a stunning
landscape of jagged peaks, snow patches and alpine lakes. We found it more
intoxicating than any microbrew.

Then it started hailing on us. Yes, in midsummer balls of ice the size of
marbles pelted us, stinging through hats and clothing. Soon the ice turned to
rain, the trail to mud -- and we were reminded that one of the great things
about the wilderness is its capacity to discomfort and humble us.

Most of the time in the 21st century, we dominate our surroundings: We tweak the
thermostat and the temperature falls one degree. We push a button and Taylor
Swift sings for us. It's the opposite in the wilderness, which teaches us
constantly that we are not lords of the universe but rather building blocks of
it.

In the best sense, nature puts us in our place. Sometimes with icy toes.

Wilderness offers therapy for the soul as just about the last fully egalitarian
place in America. Here we all stand equal -- before the bears and the
mosquitoes. And there's a lesson here worth emulating for the rest of America.

I invite you to sign up for my free, twice-weekly newsletter. When you do,
you'll receive an email about my columns as they're published and other
occasional commentary. Sign up here.I also invite you to visit my blog, On the
Ground. Please also join me on Facebook and Google+, watch my YouTube videos and
follow me on Twitter.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/opinion/sunday/nicholas-kristof-this-land-is-o
ur-land.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: A section of the Pacific Crest Trail in central California. The
trail extends south to Mexico and north to Canada. (PHOTOGRAPH BY NICHOLAS
KRISTOF/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: REAL ESTATE (90%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (90%); HIKING (89%);
BACKPACKING (89%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (77%); LAKES (73%); CONSTRUCTION (73%);
MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (71%); MOUNTAINS (70%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (65%); PLASTIC
FILM SHEETS & BAGS (61%); HEDGE FUNDS (56%)

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (92%); WASHINGTON, USA (92%); WEST USA (79%)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); BAHAMAS (92%); CANADA (68%)

                               The New York Times

                             August 30, 2015 Sunday

The Summer That Never Was

BYLINE: By TIM KREIDER.

Tim Kreider is the author of ''We Learn Nothing,'' a collection of essays and
cartoons.

SECTION: Section SR; Column 0; Sunday Review Desk; OPINION; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1288 words


I NEVER went to Iceland. I suppose I should say I didn't go to Iceland this
summer -- never sounds a little melodramatic, possibly terminal. It's not as if
I've died and all hope of ever having gone to Iceland is obviated. But for some
reason this missed opportunity is causing me more than the usual, near-toxic
level of regret. I've had a free apartment in Reykjavik on offer for several
years, and somehow I've never made it there. The owner of the apartment sends me
photos of the aurora borealis that break my heart.

This was going to be the summer I finally went. Airfares were cheap. I'd just
finished writing a book in May, and for the first time in three years the awful
obligation to Work on My Book was not weighing on my soul. The summer looked as
wide open and shimmering with possibility as the summers of childhood.

But events conspired against me. I just couldn't afford the flight until some
checks I was waiting on arrived, and though all other transactions in the 21st
century are conducted electronically and instantaneously, the process of paying
writers is apparently still carried out by scriveners and counting-houses and
small boys dispatched with shillings in their hands, so by the time I got the
money I'd run out of summer.

Other unexpected complications arose, as they always do. I'd also intended to be
less of a recluse this summer, to see old friends more often, make regular trips
down to Baltimore and have visitors at my cabin every weekend. But just before
the Fourth of July, a friend and former editor of mine nearly severed her little
toe falling down the stairs at my house, and was laid up on crutches at my place
for the next few weeks. She tried to be as independent as possible, but there
are limits to what a woman can do with two surgical pins in her toe, so my job
became to make her tea, fetch things for her and occasionally carry her from
place to place like Mr. Alexander's bodyguard in ''A Clockwork Orange.''

She'd recovered enough to go home by the end of July, and I've been frantically
trying to cram all the idle goofing off I didn't get to do all summer into the
last few weeks, but goofing off isn't the sort of thing you can cram.

Every reminder of forgone pleasures -- the empty hammock I hardly ever lay in, a
little sugar-cube melon that went bad before I'd even cut one slice from it --
makes me want to cry. This end-of-summer melancholy is a common experience, even
a cliché. Part of it of course is just my dread and hatred of back-to-school
time, unchanged since childhood. The whole world of work and productivity still
seems to me like an unconscionable waste of time; the only parts of life that
really matter are the summers, the in-between times -- the idle goofing off.

But there's more to it than that. I use the word ''never'' in my Icelandic
lament because there really is attached to it a sense of desolation, as of a
possibility lost forever. For me, at least, it feels less like ''melancholy,''
which is a gentle, almost pleasant emotion, and more like terror. It's only a
superficial throb of a pain that goes much deeper, in the same way that those
few oddly cool days in August are the first innocuous evidence of an entire
planet tilting inexorably into the shadow. It's entangled, somewhere down there,
with the existential panic of aging. Of time passing, the calendar running out,
things left undone.

I don't think I'm belaboring a metaphor here; I think that's what this feeling
is really about. I'm not old but I'm not young anymore, either, and if you're a
procrastinator and a ditherer like me you can manage to sustain until well into
midlife the delusion that you might yet get around to doing all the things you
meant to do; making a movie, getting married, living in Paris. But at some point
you start to suspect that you might not end up doing that stuff after all, and
have to consider the possibility that the life you have right now might pretty
much be it.

However, this also allows you to consider your actual life, instead of comparing
it to the imaginary one you plotted out at age 12, or back in May. The spring
romance I'd hoped might turn into a lasting relationship culminated, instead, in
an awkward overnight visit. But then I found myself involved with someone made
sanguine by tragedy, with the alien capacity to appreciate whatever happiness
comes her way without either second-guessing it to death or grasping at it and
clamoring for more. She's a hypnotherapist, and I've been thinking of asking her
whether it'd be possible to inculcate a similar quality in me.

Because although I didn't go to Iceland this summer, I did take care of a
friend. The time my ex-editor and I spent as invalid and manservant was kind of
like going on a cross-country road trip or to sleep-away camp together. We ended
up with a hundred in-jokes and nicknames. We're now less like friends than
siblings, meaning that we may hate each other briefly but we're doomed to love
each other forever. Once you've carried someone in your arms while she's weeping
and bleeding, you're never going to be indifferent to her again.

I didn't go to Iceland, but I watched ''Zapped!'' and ate Taco Bell in a
hospital bed, played cornhole at a pleasure club (not what it sounds like),
spent indolent afternoons drinking wine on a back porch in Baltimore and opened
a humane mousetrap only to have the captive mouse leap straight into my face
while a friend was trying to leave an ''out-of-office'' voice mail message,
which suddenly erupted into a chaos of little-girl screams and berserk cursing.
I swam naked in the Chesapeake Bay, made martinis at 5 every day, watched
fireflies after dark. I saw a Perseid meteor streak across the night sky and
vanish so fast it was hard to tell whether its incandescent trail was in the
atmosphere, on my retina, or only in memory.

I suspect that the way I feel now, at summer's end, is about how I'll feel at
the end of my life, assuming I have time and mind enough to reflect: bewildered
by how unexpectedly everything turned out, regretful about all the things I
didn't get around to, clutching the handful of friends and funny stories I've
amassed, and wondering where it all went. And I'll probably still be evading the
same truth I'm evading now: that the life I ended up with, much as I complain
about it, was pretty much the one I chose. And my dissatisfactions with it are
really with my own character, with my hesitation and timidity.

In a couple of weeks I'll resume teaching for the fall, and start boarding up my
psyche for another hateful winter in New York. But the summer's insatiate lust
for travel still torments me. A couple of weeks ago I went to the American
Museum of Natural History with some friends and their kids, and it occurred to
me, looking at the beautiful dioramas of Animals of North America, that I would
go to this museum to look at the dioramas even without any animals in them. It's
like a peep show of nature for New Yorkers. Those realistic vistas of Alaskan
glaciers, the Great Plains and Yosemite National Park pull at my insides with a
wanting that hurts. God, how I long to go out West again someday -- to drive
some blue highway in Nevada or Utah until there's absolutely nothing around me,
then stop the car, in the middle of the road, maybe, and get out and just stand
there, where I can see the horizon in every direction, and smell the air and
feel the sun and listen to the silence of the desert. I have this idea that if I
could do this, time might hold still for a second, and I would know, for just a
moment, what it feels like to be here.

Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up
for the Opinion Today newsletter.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/opinion/sunday/the-summer-that-never-was.html

GRAPHIC: DRAWING (DRAWING BY ROMAN MURADOV) (SR4-SR5)

Genevieve Kimberlin, Devon Jarvis

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 218 words


Genevieve Steele Kimberlin, a daughter of Joni S. Kimberlin and Kevin B.
Kimberlin of Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday to Devon Michael Jarvis, a
son of Carol A. Jarvis and Jackson M. Jarvis of Fairfield, Iowa. The Rev. Jack
Davidson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the First
Congregational Church in Old Greenwich.

Mrs. Jarvis, 28, manages the corporate outreach program and is an instructor at
the David Lynch Foundation in New York, started by the filmmaker David Lynch to
offer transcendental meditation to reduce stress and trauma. She graduated from
Boston College. Her father is the chairman of Spencer Trask & Company, a venture
capital firm in Greenwich. Her mother is a documentary filmmaker whose most
recent production,''Get Real! Wise Women Speak,'' was shown on public television
in 2011.

Mr. Jarvis, 26, is an associate in business development at the Global Atlantic
Financial Group in New York. He graduated from the University of Iowa. His
mother is a freelance web and graphic designer in Fairfield. His father
maintains the payroll program for representatives of Cambridge Investment
Research, a company in Fairfield that provides stockbroker services.

The couple met when a mutual friend brought Mr. Jarvis to a birthday party in
Manhattan for Ms. Kimberlin.

A Decade After Katrina, New Orleans Is Partying Again, and Still Rebuilding

BYLINE: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; National Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 923 words


NEW ORLEANS --  ''Today is ceiling drywall,'' said Dani Babon, a 24-year-old
site supervisor for the St. Bernard Project, a volunteer group that was started
the year after Hurricane Katrina.

Ten years ago to the day, the Hendersons' house on Amelia Street was flooded by
six and a half feet of water, and Carl Henderson sat in a friend's place and
watched bodies float through town.

On Saturday, the house was filled with young people measuring, cutting and
drilling. Not that different, Ms. Babon said, from any other day.

Hurricane Katrina made landfall on Aug. 29, 2005, and wrecked the Mississippi
gulf coast. Shortly after, the levees around New Orleans breached and drowned
most of the city. More than a thousand died, more than a million homes and
businesses were damaged or destroyed, and a mass exodus took place -- a period
of exile that for many has not ended.

On the same date in 2015, the weather was not as hot as usual for this time of
year. This was all the better for the day's lineup of events: citywide volunteer
projects, prayer services, festivals and wreath layings. Multiple parades took
place, including a hundreds-strong second line parade, as the tradition is
called here, featuring wave after wave of brass bands and dancing clubs. The
parade rolled from the Lower Ninth Ward and down St. Claude Avenue, swelling as
people joined along the way.

''After pain and sorrow, we get the second line bands together and listen to
music and celebrate,'' said Shade Smith, 28, who was stranded for three days by
the floodwaters in an apartment at the St. Bernard public housing project, until
a family rowed by with a boat. ''That's just how people reunite after something
really sad, to celebrate a tragedy.''

The marquee event was in the early evening at the Smoothie King Center, the
city's professional basketball arena, where national political figures spoke,
Mardi Gras Indians chanted, musicians sang and religious leaders prayed.

Former President Bill Clinton -- the third president to visit New Orleans in
three days -- recalled coming here as a 3-year-old, the first city he had ever
visited, and later as a 15-year-old aspiring jazz musician.

In brief comments, he urged the city to celebrate the accomplishments of the
past 10 years but not to ignore the profound racial and economic disparities
that remain.

It has been a week of art exhibits, dinners, panels and lectures -- a week of
extended discussions about what the last 10 years have been about, without
arriving at any real consensus. There have been city-sanctioned talks about the
recovery as ''a model for urban America'' and summit meetings about ''the
capitalist crimes inflicted on New Orleans's working class.''

The official anniversary commemoration had its own logo, its own color scheme
and its own ubiquitous buzzword: resilience. The message from many civic and
business leaders was that the city was better than ever, or at least on track to
be.

Yet playing underneath it all was the counterpoint of shootings, the unchanging
routine of workers in the low-wage tourist economy and the occasional outbursts
of raw grief from those reminded of the worst period of their lives.

''I think a lot of people have been kind of hunkering down and feeling
ambivalent at best,'' said Justin Wolfe, a history professor at Tulane
University here. ''It feels like we're this spectacle, and yet in all that
spectacle, the horror of so much of what happened, the tribulation but also how
many people ended up on the wrong side of that story, that gets lost.''

Still, an aversion to the onslaught of attention from the news media was mixed
with a gratitude that so many people still feel invested in this city. More than
100 volunteers have worked at the Henderson house over the last few weeks, doing
in that time what had not been done in 10 years of inadequate government
disaster assistance, contractor fraud, break-ins and continuing bureaucratic
nightmares.

''It's not a celebration -- it's a headache,'' Roberta Henderson said of the
day's significance, describing the litany of stress-induced health problems that
her husband, Carl, has endured since the first days after the flood. ''Many
people wouldn't have lasted through this. They would have just died or given
up.''

The Hendersons expect to move back into their home by Thanksgiving. By Saturday
morning, the St. Bernard Project had rebuilt 615 homes in New Orleans, though
its leaders emphasize that there is still a very long way to go.

Elsewhere around the city on Saturday, life went on quietly.

''We work during the week, so this is the day we clean up,'' said Larry Sambo,
60, who on Saturday morning was washing the family car on a street in Gentilly,
a part of town that was under more than seven feet of water.

He and his wife, Arlene, ran through their own brief Katrina commemoration:
evacuation, months of moving around the South, three years in a trailer,
insufficient rebuilding aid, dishonest plumbers, higher taxes, higher insurance
costs and a street full of new neighbors.

''Katrina made things worse for us,'' Ms. Sambo said. ''We take it one day at a
time.''

In the evening, around the same time as the event in the Smoothie King Center,
the annual midsummer Mardi Gras parade was scheduled to roll uptown. The
announcement on Facebook encouraged those attending to wear their costumes. It
concluded with this clarification: ''Please note that although this parade falls
on Aug. 29, it is not an event commemorating the anniversary of Katrina.''




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/us/a-decade-after-katrina-new-orleans-is-party
ing-again-and-still-rebuilding.html

traveling through New Orleans's Lower Ninth Ward, part of a day of community
activities on the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY EDMUND
FOUNTAIN/REUTERS

lineup included volunteer projects, prayer services, festivals and wreath
layings. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JOE RAEDLE/GETTY IMAGES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

(86%); SINGERS & MUSICIANS (86%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (77%); PARADES & MARCHES

In the Belly of the Beast

BYLINE: By ANDREW COTTO

SECTION: Section MB; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 564 words


Heading out toward eastern Long Island, just before the patina of the Hamptons'
wealth starts to emerge, the Montauk Highway slips past quaint hamlets and faded
farmhouses and watery fingers of Moriches Bay. On the roadside in Center
Moriches, through a yawning shark's mouth, Atlantic Seafood Restaurant and Fish
Market offers a bounty from the sea -- to eat in, take out or prepare at home --
but the main attraction is the welcoming feel of the place, orchestrated by the
establishment's owner, Dennis Donovan, a local for 50 years.

Mr. Donovan is one of 10 children who relocated to Center Moriches from the
Bronx when he was 6. As a teenager he worked in a bakery. After high school, he
and a brother-in-law owned and operated some local bakeries of their own before
Mr. Donovan opened a successful pub. He also met Chrissy Flynn, daughter of
Maryann Schultz, who was co-owner of a seafood restaurant on the side of Montauk
Highway in a former swap shop where her husband, George, built lobster traps in
retirement and where, one day, Maryann steamed a lobster for a local man as a
favor. That favor gave birth to a seafood restaurant and market in 1979 that
would be sold in 2005 to the man Ms. Flynn married, Mr. Donovan.

''Look, our lobsters are cooked just like everybody else's,'' Mr. Donovan said
on a recent weekend. So clearly, it's the place that inspires the fierce
devotion of locals and those on their way out toward tonier shores. ''We try to
do things a little different.''

Even on a Saturday night in the heart of the summer season, the restaurant and
its adjacent take-out counter and fish market hum with harmony and an overriding
sense of good will. Blue-clad waitresses come and go from behind the counter
like charming acrobats of perfect timing to the tables that flank the front
entrance. In the fish market and commissary in back, Chrissy Donovan and her
daughter, Colleen, oversee takeout orders, the purchase of fresh and frozen fish
and related groceries, chatting amiably with customers while staying in constant
motion.

The prepared food comes from the silent kitchen in back, manned by Mr. and Mrs.
Donovan's son Denny and Benjamin Bravo, an Atlantic Seafood veteran of 25 years.
The senior Dennis is everywhere, still brimming with energy after a day that
began at 4 a.m. to buy fresh fish from South Shore docks and inlets, like every
other day in the nonstop summer season. He shakes hands, slaps backs, asks after
family, helps with orders, rings up tabs, clears tables and takes a knee for
conversations with seated customers, looking squarely in their eyes.

Seated for dinner recently at a table underneath a ceiling hung with nets among
walls adorned with maritime bric-a-brac were Mike and Marissa Morris, both 39,
with their 5-year-old daughter and her newborn baby sister.

''We come in quite regularly,'' Mr. Morris said, ''and nobody's going to look at
us like we have three heads if our kid cries a bit. It's very laid back. It's
family.''

''People who grew up here, stay here,'' Ms. Morris added. ''We know the
waitresses. We know everybody.''

And that's what makes the lobster Mr. Morris is eating different from one easily
found elsewhere: It's procured and prepared and served in an environment
fostered by the philosophy of a local Moriches boy (via the Bronx) made good.
And you get to pass through a shark's mouth to eat there.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/nyregion/a-toothy-welcome-to-a-family-fish-res
taurant-on-long-island.html

THE NEW YORK TIMES)
