George Cleve, Conductor Who Interpreted Mozart, Dies at 79

BYLINE: By MARGALIT FOX

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Obituary; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 518 words


George Cleve, a conductor known to New York audiences for his guest appearances
with the Mostly Mozart Festival and the New York City Ballet, died on Thursday
at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 79.

The cause was liver failure, said Khori Dastoor, a family friend.

Renowned as a Mozart interpreter, Mr. Cleve spent his career primarily on the
West Coast. He was the music director of the San Jose Symphony from 1972 to 1992
and in 1974 founded the Midsummer Mozart Festival, an annual concert series in
the Bay Area that he directed to the end of his life.

Mr. Cleve appeared as a guest conductor with orchestras around the world,
including the New York and Los Angeles Philharmonics; the Boston, San Francisco
and Montreal Symphonies; the Cleveland Orchestra; the Royal Philharmonic
Orchestra of London, the Israel Philharmonic, the Vienna Symphony and the
Orchestre National de France.

The distinguished soloists with whom he worked over the years included the
pianists Van Cliburn, Peter Serkin and André Watts; the violinists Henryk
Szeryng and Joshua Bell; the cellist Mischa Maisky; and the French horn player
Barry Tuckwell.

George Wolfgang Cleve was born in Vienna on July 9, 1936, to an artistic family.
His father, Felix, was a philosopher, violinist and newspaper film and dance
critic; his mother, the former Melitta Monheit, taught foreign languages and
played the piano. An aunt, Fanny Cleve, was a prominent soprano who sang under
the batons of Richard Strauss, George Szell and Otto Klemperer.

The Cleves, who were Jewish, fled Austria after the Nazi annexation of 1938,
settling in New York in 1940. As a youth, George studied the piano and violin,
graduating from the High School of Music & Art in Manhattan.

He went on to study at the Mannes College of Music, and at Tanglewood he worked
with the conductor Pierre Monteux, who became a longtime mentor.

Mr. Cleve made his New York Philharmonic debut in 1965 in a program that
included Mozart, Liszt and Berlioz. Reviewing the concert in The New York Times,
Harold C. Schonberg wrote: ''Mr. Cleve turned out to be a most talented young
man and one who steps on the podium completely assured of his right to be there.
His confidence is not misplaced.''

After holding conducting posts with the Winnipeg Symphony and the Iceland
Symphony, Mr. Cleve assumed the music directorship of the San Jose Symphony. (He
was succeeded there in 1992 by Leonid Grin; the orchestra ceased operations in
2001.)

Mr. Cleve made his Mostly Mozart debut in 1975 and over the next quarter-century
returned to the festival more than half a dozen times.

He was also a frequent guest conductor with the New York City Ballet, making his
debut there in 2000 in the world premiere of Twyla Tharp's ''The Beethoven
Seventh.'' Over the next several years, Mr. Cleve conducted performances by the
company that included George Balanchine's ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier'' and his
''Symphony in C,'' both to the music of Bizet.

Mr. Cleve's survivors include his wife, Maria Tamburrino, a flutist, whom he
married in 1986; a son, Jeremiah Wiggins; and a granddaughter.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/arts/music/george-cleve-conductor-who-interpre
ted-mozart-dies-at-79.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: George Cleve in 2003. He was a guest conductor for New York City
Ballet, and also appeared at the Mostly Mozart Festival. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JOANNE
HOYOUNG LEE/SAN JOSE MERCURY NEWS)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Premieres for Summer's End

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; CLASSICAL; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 169 words


The week leading up to Labor Day is typically the least-scheduled stretch in New
York's classical music season. But the intrepid Bargemusic, Brooklyn's floating
recital hall, always steps into the brink with a gala program. It does so this
week with ''Here and Now Labor Day Festival,'' an ambitious contemporary music
program, repeated four times, offering nine works in either world or New York
premieres. There are premieres of two pieces by Dalit Warshaw; a solo cello
Soliloquy by Andrew Rudin; David Del Tredici's Duo for Violin and Cello (''To Be
Sung on the Water''); Richard Sussman's Trio for Violin, Piano and Laptop; and
David Taylor's Concertino for Bass Trombone and Trio. Works by Morton Subotnick,
John Zorn and Gordon Beeferman receive New York premieres. Among the enticing
roster of 11 performers are the pianist Kathleen Supové, the violinist Jennifer
Choi and the bassoonist Peter Kolkay. (8 p.m., Wednesday, Friday and Saturday,
with a final performance next Sunday at 4 p.m., bargemusic.org.)

URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/arts/music/bargemusics-here-and-now-labor-day-
festival.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Kathleen Supové on piano and Jennifer Choi on violin.
(PHOTOGRAPH BY ETIENNE FROSSARD)

Francesca Chubb-Confer, Alexander Higgin-Houser

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 210 words


Francesca Nicole Chubb-Confer, the daughter of Judith A. Chubb of Bolton, Mass.,
and the late Charles L. Confer, is to be married Sunday at her mother's house to
Alexander Brian Higgin-Houser, a son of Doreen K. Higgin-Houser and Brian E.
Higgin-Houser of Burnsville, Minn. Janet Slagle, a maternal aunt of the bride,
received authorization from Massachusetts to officiate.

The couple met at Carleton College in Northfield, Minn., from which they
graduated magna cum laude.

The bride, 27, is keeping her name. She has a master's in Islamic studies from
the University of Chicago, where she is seeking a Ph.D. in that subject area.

Her mother is a distinguished professor in ethics and society and a professor of
political science at Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass. The bride's father was the
head engineer at Thermetrix, a company that provided thermal imaging equipment.

The groom, 28, is the artistic director of the Underscore Theater Company in
Chicago and the festival director for the Chicago Musical Theater Festival.

His mother is the manager of the behavioral research laboratory at the Carlson
School of Management at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. His father
is a computer systems analyst in St. Paul for the Army Corps of Engineers.

By the Book: Ann Beattie

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1299 words


The author, most recently, of ''The State We're In'' reads more novels and
stories than anything else -- ''except, maybe, cookbooks. I avoid mysteries,
since I never understand what happens.''

What books are currently on your night stand?

''Memphis Movie,'' by Corey Mesler; ''Paragon Park,'' by Mark Doty; ''Kinder
Than Solitude,'' by Yiyun Li; ''Looking at Photographs,'' by Gordon Baldwin and
Martin Jurgens; ''Metaphysical Dog: Poems,'' by Frank Bidart; ''The New York
Stories of Elizabeth Hardwick.'' The magazines I have yet to read are layered
between these books like phyllo.

Do you have a favorite novel of all time?

Maybe Ian McEwan's ''Atonement.''

What are your all-time favorite short stories?

Among them: ''Twilight of the Superheroes'' and ''Your Duck Is My Duck,'' by
Deborah Eisenberg; ''Way Down Deep in the Jungle,'' by Thom Jones; ''Oxygen,''
by Ron Carlson; ''Nettles'' and ''The Albanian Virgin,'' by Alice Munro; ''The
Fat Girl,'' by Andre Dubus; ''We Didn't,'' by Stuart Dybek; ''Tits-Up in a
Ditch,'' by Annie Proulx; ''Bruns,'' by Norman Rush; ''Escapes,'' by Joy
Williams; ''Yours,'' by Mary Robison; ''The Dog of the Marriage,'' by Amy
Hempel; ''The Fireman's Wife,'' by Richard Bausch; ''The Womanizer,'' by Richard
Ford; ''Helping,'' by Robert Stone; ''No Place for You, My Love,'' by Eudora
Welty; ''Are These Actual Miles,'' by Raymond Carver; ''People Like That Are The
Only People Here,'' by Lorrie Moore; ''Last Night,'' by James Salter; ''Sarah
Cole: A Type of Love Story,'' by Russell Banks; ''Hunters in the Snow,'' by
Tobias Wolff; Rebecca Lee's collection, ''Bobcat.''

Whom do you consider the best writers -- fiction writers, essayists, critics,
journalists, poets -- working today?

Gay Talese's pieces. Anything by Jeremy Denk or Susan Orlean. Patrick Modiano's
novels, and John Banville's. Alice Munro's and Elizabeth Spencer's stories.
Essays: Annie Dillard, particularly ''For the Time Being.'' Joan Didion (of
course). Joy Williams's ''Ill Nature''; Charles Baxter's ''Burning Down the
House.'' Elaine Scarry's ''Dreaming by the Book.'' John Jeremiah Sullivan.
Phillip Lopate. Charles d'Ambrosio. The essays in The American Scholar are
usually excellent. Robert Richardson's biographies. Many great poets, among them
Charles Wright, Louise Glück, Charles Simic, C. K. Williams. The book reviews in
The Times Literary Supplement are really good.

What genres do you especially enjoy reading? And which do you avoid?

I read more novels and stories than anything else except, maybe, cookbooks. I
avoid mysteries, since I never understand what happens.

What books might we be surprised to find on your shelves?

Etiquette books, but only old ones. My favorite is Amy Vanderbilt's ''New
Complete Book of Etiquette'' (1962 edition) that contains the sentence -- in an
example of a good thank-you note -- ''We have always wanted to see 'High Ridge'
in the peony season.'' It's the word ''the'' that slays me.

If you belong to a book club, tell us about it. If you don't, tell us what your
ideal book club would be like.

I change locations too often to be in a book club. It's hard enough getting the
mail forwarded. But my ideal? My friend Carla Rollins would provide the snacks.
It would only meet when someone was either right, or deluded about thinking what
he/she had read was truly amazing. It would meet late at night, because I have
insomnia and nobody to hang out with after midnight. I'd go first. My pick would
be Howard Norman's ''Next Life Might Be Kinder.'' (I'd be right.)

Who's your favorite fictional hero or heroine?

They all have their deficiencies, after years of reconsideration. But I suppose
Mrs. Ramsay, although she'd protest being called a ''heroine'' for all good
reason. I used to think it was so radical, the way the reader learns of her
death. Then I started getting informed of the totally unexpected deaths of my
friends in the subject line of email, which seems even more startling.

What kind of reader were you as a child? Your favorite books and authors?

My father liked books about finance and how to cure back pain. My mother read
widely, especially library books about Africa, biographies and Agatha Christie
mysteries. She'd often appear at my bedroom door with a mystery in hand and a
box of chocolates and say, ''If you want me, I'll be under No. 7.'' (She had an
electric blanket. How that didn't melt the chocolates, I'll never know.) She
also read aloud to me, but then as now I wandered out of the room if I didn't
immediately like what I heard. (I can make myself read a book, but I can't make
myself listen to one.) She and I read ''The Spy Who Came In From the Cold''
aloud to each other more than once. As a child, I loved ''The Secret Garden''
and the Mary Poppins books and (if I remember the title correctly) ''Bertram and
the Ticklish Rhinoceros.'' I thought ''rhinoceros'' was an inherently funny word
and used to stare at the title, when not actually rereading the book. I'm sorry
I don't still have it, though it can't possibly be as good as I remember. I
loved comic books. I also liked those little brochures about how to make
desserts with Jell-O, and 20 exciting recipes to make with lima beans. I was
always taking them from the kitchen drawer and studying them. I really liked the
illustrations.

Have you ever gotten in trouble for reading a book?

No. I read fast, and furtively, so who'd know?

If you had to name one book that made you who you are today, what would it be?

It would be upsetting to think that a book was responsible for who I am today.

Of the books you've written, which is your favorite or the most personally
meaningful?

''Another You.'' Its publication wasn't helped by The New York Times Book Review
titling the review to play on the title of the movie ''Bob & Carol & Ted &
Alice.'' No offense to Paul Mazursky, but this novel was not that.

If you could require the president to read one book, what would it be?

I never insist that people read anything (though I do have copies sent to them).
Somehow, I don't think I'll be sending one particular book to the White House.
We'd have to chat first.

You're hosting a literary dinner party. Which three writers are invited?

I'd invite Michael Silverblatt and ask him to bring any two writers he wanted.

Disappointing, overrated, just not good: What book did you feel you were
supposed to like, and didn't? Do you remember the last book you put down without
finishing?

''The Blithedale Romance.'' In a tie: ''The Sorrows of Young Werther.'' While I
don't think Robert Frost was bad, I can rarely understand a thing the man wrote.

Do you ever deliberately hate-read?

No. But I go to the gym three or four days a week and try to eat sensibly, then
sometimes eat chocolate-chip cookies at 3a.m., if that might reveal the same
thing about me.

Whom would you want to write your life story?

Harry Mathews.

What books do you find yourself returning to again and again?

''Celebrating the Negative,'' by John Loengard; ''Anthracite Country,'' by Jay
Parini; ''The Blue Strawbery Cookbook,'' by James Haller; ''Concerning the Book
That Is the Body of the Beloved,'' by Gregory Orr; ''Lolita''; Frederick
Barthelme's ''Moon Deluxe,'' among his many others. ''The Great Gatsby.''
''Almost Invisible,'' by Mark Strand (I reread two or three poems most every
day). Steven Millhauser's ''Edwin Mullhouse,'' because I open it just to reread
a page I particularly admire, then give up and start from the beginning. ''Point
Omega,'' by Don DeLillo. ''Wittgenstein's Mistress,'' by David Markson. I always
have extra copies to give away.

What books are you embarrassed not to have read yet?

''On the Road.''

What do you plan to read next?

Let's hope a new Patrick Modiano has been translated into English.




URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/books/review/ann-beattie-by-the-book.html

GRAPHIC: DRAWING (DRAWING BY JILLIAN TAMAKI)

Drilling Deep

BYLINE: By STEPHEN BURT.

Stephen Burt is the author, most recently, of a poetry collection, ''Belmont,''
and a volume of criticism, ''Close Calls With Nonsense.''

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 638 words


THAT WINTER THE WOLF CAMEBy Juliana Spahr 85 pp. Commune Editions. Paper, $16.
Nobody has to tell Juliana Spahr that the personal is political: She has spent
her career inventing verse and prose forms that show how our intimate feelings
emerge, like knots in nets or waves at sea, from systems much larger than any
one person's control. ''This Connection of Everyone With Lungs'' (2005)
Â­examined the global effects of 9/11 through the metaphor of polluted air; the
piled-up details in ''Well Then There Now'' (2011) looked at Spahr's years in
Hawaii, and at her Â­origins in Appalachia, as if to ask where she could call
home.

Now Spahr lives in the San Francisco Bay Area; she joined the encampments and
protests of Occupy Oakland in 2011, though she and her young son ''never spent
the night.'' ''That Winter the Wolf Came'' is Spahr's Occupy book: Its nine
thoughtful, wiry works (three in prose, six in verse) ask how it felt and what
it means to remain a disillusioned opponent of capitalism, a
not-quite-despondent environmental observer and an anxious parent today.

It's hard to quote Spahr in ways that show how good she is, because, phrase by
phrase, she keeps her writing austere. It depends on successive overlaps, on
slow builds, so that over several pages we discover (for example) what the BP
oil spill, the dispersal of Occupy by the police, the price of Brent crude, the
flights of brent geese and the repetitions in pop songs have in common: They let
singers ''during the ongoing oil wars'' -- or birds displaced from flight paths,
or protesters swept from a park -- ''understand something about what is being
lost.''

Land and sea, oil and water, corporations and human beings: For Spahr these
things can no longer be considered separately. Spahr and her child, and you and
I, are already caught up in the dangerous skein of financial instruments and
hydrological disequilibrium. ''I hold out my hand./ I hand over / and I pass on.
.â[#x20ac][#x2c6].â[#x20ac][#x2c6]. I hold out my hand and take engine oil
additive into me and then I pass on this engine oil additive to this other thing
that once was me, this not really me.'' That's Spahr's disconcerting description
of breast-feeding in our era of BPA and chlorinated naphthalenes. Other
connections cross national borders, link species and generate hope: ''The red
snapper spreads itself out in the artificial reefs of oil platforms,'' thriving
in the dangerous new place. To save the climate and the oceans, activists (Spahr
implies) must become as international as the fish, the tankers and the
contaminants, ''traveling through the circuits that already exist.''

Like Claudia Rankine's celebrated ''Citizen,'' Spahr's book is a set of
Â­interlocking parts, some lyrical, some starkly factual, best read whole. Like
''Citizen,'' it can leave you somber, or angrily alert, or simply impressed. Her
''poem about oil extraction in iambic pentameter'' tells the story of the
Deepwater Horizon spill blow by blow: ''It is almost at ten / O'clock when mud
begins its overflow- / Ing of the line and then on the rig floor.'' Facing the
excessive power of oil, Spahr's poetic ''line'' itself breaks up, gives way.

Yet Spahr sees a future for her radical cause. One essay remembers the
Â­movement, which she names Â­''Non-Revolution,'' as if it were a lover, with
''this odd patch of hair on its lower back'': ''I wanted to be with
Â­Non-Revolution and everyone Non-Revolution was with.'' Her last poem,
''Turnt'' (as in ''turned up'': excited or intoxicated), recreates a violent
night when she and her friends were ''turnt to mere vandals at moments.'' At
others, they saw -- and she can make us see -- a new world: ''We were together
but we were in it alone at the same time. Except the state was there with us.
.â[#x20ac][#x2c6].â[#x20ac][#x2c6]. We knew history. We knew we would not be
together long.''

ana-spahr.html

Janna Burke, Gregory Spock

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 262 words


Janna Claire Burke and Gregory Michael Spock were married Saturday. The Rev.
Carol Rosine, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Wequassett
Resort and Golf Club in Harwich, Mass.

Mrs. Spock, 31, is the director for individual giving at the Fashion Institute
of Technology Foundation, which supports the SUNY design school in New York. She
graduated from Muhlenberg College in Allentown, Pa., and received a master's
degree in music from Duquesne University in Pittsburgh.

She is the daughter of Jean C. Burke and Joseph C. Burke of Norfolk, Mass. The
bride's father is a marketing consultant for software companies. Her mother is a
financial planner. Both work from Norfolk.

Mr. Spock, also 31, is a real estate agent in New York for Stribling &
Associates. He graduated from Syracuse University.

He is a son of Linda Ciricillo Spock and Wayne R. Spock of Delray Beach, Fla.
The groom's mother retired as a clinical psychologist in Hartford. His father
retired as the chief engineer for air-management systems in the Hamilton
Sundstrand division of United Technologies in Hartford.

The couple, amateur opera singers who met in 2009 when both were part of a Bronx
Opera production, became engaged last July, while vacationing in Wellfleet,
Mass. The groom, who dropped to one knee after serenading Ms. Burke with an aria
from ''La Bohème,'' later explained that early in their relationship the heat in
his East Village building had failed and Ms. Burke took him in. ''It was
parallel to the story in 'La Bohème,' '' he said, ''but sort of in the
reverse.''

Marina Bousa, Patrick Morrissey

Marina Louise Bousa, a daughter of Maureen F. Bousa and Edward P. Bousa of
Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married Saturday to Patrick Joseph Morrissey, the
son of Susan White Morrissey of New York and the late Kevin P. Morrissey. The
Rev. Richard W. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church
of St. Mary, Our Lady of the Isle, in Nantucket, Mass.

The couple met at Williams College, from which they graduated.

Mrs. Morrissey, 25, is an actor currently appearing in a production of ''Vanya
and Sonia and Masha and Spike'' at the Dreamland Theater in Nantucket. She is
also a second-year student in the M.F.A. program in acting at Brown University,
in Providence.

Her father is a partner and a senior portfolio manager at Wellington Management,
an investment company in Boston. Her mother is a trustee of Historic New
England, a preservation organization, and the Nantucket Historical Association,
which operates a whaling museum and historic sites on the island.

Mr. Morrissey, 26, is a research assistant in Providence, studying sudden
cardiac death and other subjects, at Rhode Island Hospital and at the Brown
University Cardiovascular Research Center. He completed postbaccalaureate
studies in pre-medicine at Bennington College in June.

His mother is the founder and chief executive of White & Warren, a cashmere
clothing wholesale and retail company in New York. His father was an executive
vice president and the general merchandising manager for men's wear at Macy's in
New York.

Do We Mistake Inaccessibility for Brilliance?

Inventive Menus in Mitte

BYLINE: By GISELA WILLIAMS

SECTION: Section TR; Column 0; Travel Desk; BITES; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 407 words


On a recent Thursday evening in the fashionable neighborhood of Mitte, a crowd
of artists and D.J.s descended on a large marble-top table loaded with seasonal
dishes: radishes served with freshly churned kefir butter; Dutch oysters
flavored with ponzu ginger and chile. Within 20 minutes, the platters were
empty. This record release party took place at the Store Kitchen, a new
restaurant within a recently opened design emporium called the Store, off the
lobby of Soho House.

''They demolished the food,'' said Tommy Tannock, one of the two British chefs
at the Store Kitchen. ''Berlin hipsters love a free meal.''

Even when the food is not free, the Store Kitchen has been attracting a
fashionable mixed crowd of local food lovers, seasoned vegans, creative types
working on their laptops and expats craving healthy fare.

Located in the center of the Store -- a huge, loftlike space shaped like an L --
the Store Kitchen has proved to be the heart of the place since its soft opening
this spring. A large curved bar offers up a daily-changing buffet of ambitious,
vegetable-focused dishes, like a salad of kale with barley, squash, hazelnut and
sage. There are also toasts topped with smoked line-caught trout or chunks of
avocado, and vegan raw brownies and extravagant cakes from a local baker.

''We have a very similar point of view,'' Mr. Tannock said, referring to his
partner, Johnnie Collins, ''and basically want to serve what we like to eat,
which means dishes made from fresh, seasonal and ethically sourced
ingredients.''

Customers pick up their dishes at the counter and then sit at one of about 10
colorfully designed tables. Starting next month, the Store Kitchen will spread
to another section of the space and offer dinner service, serving small plates
and a quirky menu of biodynamic wines.

At the record party, Mr. Collins looked up at the hungry crowd and excused
himself. ''I need to bring out dessert.'' Ten minutes later he returned with a
large ceramic platter covered in fudgy vegan brownies served alongside coconut
kefir pudding.

''Dip the brownie in there,'' he said -- the kefir added a bright acidic tang to
the rich brownies -- then he left again to deliver them to a nearby table. Five
minutes later they were all gone.

The Store Kitchen at The Store, Torstrasse 1; 49-30-405-044-550;
thestore-berlin.com. Average meal for two, without drinks or tip, is about 16
euros, $17 at $1.08 to the euro.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/travel/berlin-store-kitchen-restaurant-review.
html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Among the vegetable-focused dishes, a chickpea, celery and
radish salad. GRAPHIC

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: MEAT FREE DIETS (90%); RESTAURANTS (78%); ARTISTS & PERFORMERS (78%);
RETAIL BAKERIES (76%)

CITY: BERLIN, GERMANY (91%)

COUNTRY: GERMANY (91%)

                               The New York Times

                             August 30, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

The Water Receded. The Anger's Still Here.

BYLINE: By JOHN BIGUENET.

John Biguenet is the author, most recently, of ''The Rising Water Trilogy:
Plays'' and the forthcoming nonfiction book ''Silence.''

SECTION: Section SR; Column 0; Sunday Review Desk; OPINION; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1191 words


New Orleans -- WHY are we still so angry? Even sympathetic newcomers can't quite
figure out why we New Orleanians are not over it a decade later.

But it's not just anger we feel. It's also a profound and abiding sense of loss.

I'm not talking about the things that were washed away. Like most others here,
my wife, Marsha, and I lost a great deal: 2,500 books, countless mementos of our
kids' childhood, a treasured recipe for rice pudding given to us as a wedding
present and, of course, a car, furniture, clothing -- just about everything.

But we count ourselves lucky. No family members died. Homeless at first,
sleeping in a day care center, where I wrote a series of eyewitness columns for
The New York Times, we still had our jobs at least. We were able to gut and
rebuild our home. We were able to stay in New Orleans. So it's hard to explain
it to newcomers, to outsiders, our anger and our sorrow.

To be fair to them, I have to admit it's difficult to grasp the immensity of
what happened here. The area flooded was seven times the size of Manhattan. If
an equivalent catastrophe had struck New York in 2005, about 24,000 people would
have died as they awaited help that did not come for a week. Nearly seven
million of its eight million citizens would have spent the next year scattered
elsewhere in the country. Over two million New Yorkers would never have
returned. It's almost inconceivable, isn't it? But that's what happened to us.

But it didn't just happen to us. Our disaster was man-made. As the United States
Army Corps of Engineers finally admitted nearly a year later, its own negligence
and incompetence were responsible for the flooding of the city. Despite that
admission, the corps relied on the legal immunity Congress had provided it to
evade all financial judgments.

That left us at the mercy of bottom-line insurance companies and the largess of
the federal government. Unfortunately, the government in 2005 was led by
individuals who objected to the costs of rebuilding an entire city and who
seemed intent on writing off New Orleans. Only days after the storm, the
Republican speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, summarized the prevailing
attitude of his party: ''It looks like a lot of that place could be bulldozed.''

So perhaps it's understandable why the anger of many New Orleanians continues to
simmer. Yes, maybe we should have moved on by now. Everyone encourages us to put
the levee breaches and their aftermath behind us. As we're frequently reminded,
it's been 10 years, after all.

But when you still can't get from one end of your neighborhood to the other --
as in Lakeview, for example, where I live -- because streets continue to
collapse from the saltwater that flooded the area for weeks, eroding the earth
beneath them and the infrastructure buried there, it didn't just happen 10 years
ago. It happened this morning. And like so much else here in what's left of New
Orleans, it keeps happening, day after day.

Having returned to a sweltering house five weeks after the levees collapsed, I
dragged a ruined refrigerator gushing a fetid mix of floodwater and decomposed
food from our kitchen to the front door while Marsha walked behind me dumping
undiluted bleach from gallon jugs onto the floor to stanch the stench. So now
every time we leave town for more than a day or two, we empty our refrigerator
of everything perishable.

Before we had even entered our house that first day back, we were confronted by
what looked like snow strewn across our lawn. Only as it crunched beneath our
feet did we realize it was salt from the water that had slowly evaporated. Most
of the garden we now cultivate is marsh plants, like irises, that can tolerate
our salted earth. To grow vegetables, we have built a raised bed.

Downstairs in our house, we still haven't hung any paintings even though we
promise each other every year that, as soon as hurricane season is over, we
really are going to put up a few pictures.

There is also a new financial reality that refuses to go away. I've never let
myself calculate how much money the collapse of the levees cost us. But when my
homeowner's insurance bill arrives each year, I'm reminded that insurance for my
house tripled after the flood while my deductible increased from $500 to nearly
$13,000.

Still visible today on the outside of my parents' former home is a fading X
spray painted by soldiers who broke through the roof of their two-story house
searching for the dead. A zero in one quadrant confirms that no bodies were
found. In the top quadrant of the X is the date: 9/11. That X is painted beneath
my sister's old bedroom window -- on the second floor of the house. Nearly two
weeks after the levees collapsed, the water was still at least 10 feet deep
there. The soldiers had come in a boat. Such markings still tattoo walls
throughout the city.

And every day, just a few blocks from my home, I pass houses where New
Orleanians drowned in their bedrooms or died of dehydration trapped in their
attics.

Boosters like to point out that New Orleans is younger and wealthier than it
used to be. But it's a younger city, at least in part, because with home repairs
beyond the means of those on fixed incomes and with drastically reduced medical
care available to those suffering from chronic conditions, few of the elderly
were able to return in the first few years after the flood. And if it's
wealthier, that is much more a result of the poor being dispossessed than
millionaires moving to town.

Some quietly add a third difference to ''younger and wealthier'': whiter. New
Orleans is home to 100,000 fewer African-American residents than before the
flood. For those still here, poverty has worsened, with annual median household
incomes 54 percent lower than those of white families -- and 20 percent lower
than black households nationally. Not surprisingly, black neighborhoods have
been much slower than white ones to rebuild.

From the time of the city's founding, African-Americans have played a defining
role in shaping the culture of New Orleans, a culture cherished by locals and
envied by the millions of visitors a year who flock to the Big Easy. With the
percentage of black New Orleanians declining, the city is undergoing a
fundamental change.

So for better and worse, we live in a new New Orleans. In the past, when locals
worried that an influx of new arrivals would change the city, I always reminded
them that people don't change New Orleans -- New Orleans changes people. But
with the cultural memory of the elderly lost, with the post-flood demographics
altering the delicate ecology of a community unlike any other in the United
States, I wonder if my ready answer is still true.

An outpost at the mouth of the continent's greatest river, New Orleans has
survived fires and plagues and wars and hurricanes over the centuries. But in
2018, when those of us still here commemorate the 300th anniversary of the
city's founding, will we play the slow dirges of a funeral procession to bury
something we loved or the raucous tunes we were taught by our grandparents, as
we dance home from the cemetery, still alive?




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/opinion/sunday/new-orleans-the-big-uneasy.html

Ashley Beach, Brian Brooks

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 272 words


Ashley Broyhill Beach, a daughter of Marilyn Broyhill Beach and Robert T. Beach
of Winston-Salem, N.C., was married Saturday to Brian Lee Brooks, a son of
Martha Kelley Brooks of Nashville and Philip B. Brooks of Westwood Hills, Kan.
The Rev. Dr. Michael B. Brown performed the ceremony at Centenary United
Methodist Church in Winston-Salem, with the Rev. Katharine W. May, who is the
associate minister for children at the church, taking part.

Mrs. Brooks, 28, is an assistant vice president for business banking in the
Winston-Salem offices of Wells Fargo Bank. She graduated from New York
University and received an M.B.A. from Wake Forest.

Her father retired as a partner in Salem Investment Counselors, a portfolio
manager in Winston-Salem. Her mother is on the boards of Senior Services and the
Children's Law Center of Central North Carolina, both in Winston-Salem.

The bride's maternal grandfather, James T. Broyhill of Winston-Salem, is a
former Republican United States senator from North Carolina. Her paternal
grandfather, the late P. Goff Beach of Madison, Wis., was the chairman of Oscar
Mayer Foods. Her great-grandfather, J.E. Broyhill, was a founder of Broyhill
Furniture Industries.

Mr. Brooks, 34, is a vice president for market-risk management at Branch Banking
and Trust Company in Winston-Salem. He graduated from the University of Oklahoma
and received an M.B.A. from the University of Oxford in England.

His mother is a nanny in Nashville. His father is the vice president of the
Foundation Properties Corporation, a company in Wichita, Kan., that develops and
manages residential communities for the elderly.

Encarnacion Drives in Nine as Blue Jays Pound Tigers

BYLINE: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Section SP; Column 0; Sports Desk; ROUNDUP; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 393 words


Edwin Encarnacion hit three homers and tied a Toronto record by driving in nine
runs Saturday as the Blue Jays routed the visiting Detroit Tigers, 15-1.

Encarnacion extended his hitting streak to 24 games, the longest in the majors
this season, with a three-run homer off Buck Farmer (0-3) in the first inning.

Encarnacion hit a two-run shot off Guido Knudson in the sixth, then connected
for a grand slam, his third of the season, against Alex Wilson in the seventh as
the Blue Jays battered away.

RANGERS 4, ORIOLES 3 Bobby Wilson lined a tiebreaking single with two outs in
the sixth inning, and Adrian Beltre hit his 13th home run as host Texas beat
Baltimore.

The Rangers widened their lead for the second American League wild-card spot to
a game and a half.

ASTROS 4, TWINS 1 Mike Fiers followed his no-hitter with another stellar start
for Houston, pitching into the seventh inning with three hits allowed in a
victory at Minnesota.

INDIANS 8, ANGELS 3 Yan Gomes's eighth-inning grand slam capped a five-run
rally, and Cleveland defeated visiting Los Angeles.

CARDINALS 6, GIANTS 0 Lance Lynn pitched neatly into the eighth inning before
leaving with an ankle injury that was not considered serious, beating host San
Francisco for the first time as St. Louis blanked the Giants.

ROYALS 6, RAYS 3 Mike Moustakas had three hits and drove in three runs as Kansas
City won at Tampa Bay.

NATIONALS 5, MARLINS 1 Clint Robinson and Ian Desmond hit back-to-back home
runs, Jordan Zimmermann pitched seven innings, and Washington beat visiting
Miami.

PIRATES 4, ROCKIES 3 A resurgent J. A. Happ worked into the sixth inning, Aramis
Ramirez hit a three-run homer, and host Pittsburgh held off Colorado.

REDS 12, BREWERS 9 Joey Votto put the visiting Reds ahead with a two-run home
run in the ninth inning, and Cincinnati came back to beat Milwaukee.

ATHLETICS 3, DIAMONDBACKS 2 Stephen Vogt hit a homer into the Chase Field
swimming pool and drove in three runs as Oakland beat Arizona.

MARINERS 7, WHITE SOX 6 Kyle Seager hit a two-run homer during a three-run first
inning, and Seattle held on in Chicago.

PHILLIES 4, PADRES 3 Adam Morgan pitched six strong innings and drove in the
eventual winning run for host Philadelphia.

The Phillies' Aaron Altherr singled in the fifth inning, breaking his string of
seven extra-base hits to start his career.

Rangers Rise After Trip to Woodshed

BYLINE: By TYLER KEPNER

SECTION: Section SP; Column 0; Sports Desk; EXTRA BASES; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1447 words


The bold summer revival of the Texas Rangers began immediately after they hit
bottom. On July 28, three days before the nonwaiver trading deadline, the
Rangers scored five runs in the first inning against the Yankees. Then they gave
up the next 21 runs of the game, without getting a hit.

''That was a sobering moment,'' said Jon Daniels, the Rangers' general manager,
whose team fell to 47-52 with that loss. He was not interested in renting a
pitcher for the stretch drive.

''But we knew that this off-season, we were going to need to address our
pitching staff,'' Daniels said. ''How much of that work could we do right now?''

By planning for the long term, Daniels said, the Rangers could also benefit from
whatever help the new players might provide this season. And with two starters
returning from injuries, he was not quite ready to concede, anyway.

So the day after the thumping by the Yankees, the Rangers agreed to an
eight-player deal with the Philadelphia Phillies. Texas got the ace starter Cole
Hamels and reliever Jake Diekman. The Phillies got five prospects and the
left-hander Matt Harrison.

Starter Martin Perez had just come back from a torn elbow ligament. Another
starter, Derek Holland, was on his way back from a shoulder problem. Daniels
added Sam Dyson, a young reliever with a power sinker, in a deal with Miami.

The moves stabilized the pitching staff, and the offense -- including Prince
Fielder, who missed most of last season with a neck injury, and new additions
like Mike Napoli and Will Venable -- has been among the best in the American
League during the second half of the season. The Rangers won 19 of their next 28
games, starting the day after the Yankees debacle, and held the lead for the
second A.L. wild-card spot through Friday. Hamels is 2-1 in five starts, with a
3.89 E.R.A.

In Hamels, 31, they have an affordable ace for years to come. The Rangers had
pursued him in a trade in 2012, before he signed a six-year, $144 million
contract extension with the Phillies. They reopened trade talks last winter, and
the Phillies promised to scout the Rangers' farm system for a match.

As part of the trade, the Phillies included $9.5 million and absorbed Harrison's
contract, meaning the Rangers got Hamels for less than $14 million per year,
through 2018.

''We feel like with the body, the athlete, how easy he does it, the changeup,
the command -- those things all added up for the long term,'' Daniels said. ''If
he loses a tick velocity-wise, with his command of the changeup, the curveball
and the cutter, he's got weapons.''

If Yu Darvish returns from Tommy John surgery next spring, as expected, Hamels
will have another star to join him atop the rotation. The Rangers, who were
ravaged by injuries last season and lost 95 games, never dwelled on the loss of
Darvish. Daniels credited the new manager, Jeff Banister, for his positive
approach.

''We knew going into the year that we had a lot of open-ended questions,''
Daniels said. ''Was Prince going to bounce back? What about all the medical
questions on our pitchers? The new manager, the new culture, how was it all
going to come together? We had a pretty good idea we were going to get positive
answers on a lot of those questions, so we had a kind of quiet confidence. But
we had to see it.''

They saw enough to add to the roster, instead of tearing it down, even when the
record -- and the product, for one dreadful night -- looked weak. The rewards
have already begun.

The Once and Present Pitcher

He might seem to be just another pitcher with a high earned run average,
languishing in the bullpen of a struggling team. But the Philadelphia Phillies'
Adam Loewen is in the major leagues, again -- as a pitcher, again. Those facts
alone make his story remarkable.

Loewen was chosen fourth over all by Baltimore in the 2002 draft, two picks
before Zack Greinke. A left-hander from a British Columbia high school, Loewen
is the highest-drafted player ever from Canada. He reached the majors at 22.

In three seasons for the Orioles, from 2006 to 2008, his statistics did not
match his promise. Loewen had eight victories in 41 games, a 5.46 E.R.A., nearly
six walks per nine innings -- and two stress fractures in his elbow.

''Four-and-a-half-inch screw, made of titanium,'' Loewen said, gesturing to his
left elbow the other day at Citizens Bank Park. ''It's still in there. I can
kind of feel the head of the screw in the back.''

Doctors told Loewen they did not know how long it would take his elbow to
recover, if it ever did. In 2009, he joined the Toronto Blue Jays as an
outfielder, starting over in Class A. He reached the majors in September 2011,
going 6 for 32, with a homer.

But he could not escape the minors with the Mets or again with Blue Jays the
next two seasons. His 15 homers at Class AA did not inspire another team to
offer Loewen a contract for 2014, and without a backup career plan, he turned to
his arm for another chance.

After five years off from pitching, it responded well enough to earn a tryout
with the Phillies. They signed Loewen, who returned to Class A for another climb
up the ladder.

''When I started throwing off a mound again, I didn't know what was going to
happen,'' Loewen said. ''It ended up going really well. The foundation, as far
as what I was as a pitcher, was kind of laid back when I was 19 to 24. I got
some big league experience that doesn't really go away. It's always in you. So
coming back last year, it took a couple of months, and then I felt like myself
again.''

Loewen pitched well enough as a minor league starter last season, but thrived in
relief this year. He had a 2.01 E.R.A. in 40 minor league games and earned a
promotion three weeks ago. The results have been mixed -- a 6.30 E.R.A. in seven
appearances through Friday -- but Loewen said his experiences had allowed him to
think more clearly on the mound. He has been through the worst.

''As a pitcher, I always knew it was in there; it was just a matter of staying
healthy,'' he said. ''But to make it back up a third time, it's like a third
chance. I feel really grateful and blessed that my arm's responded the way it
has.''

Debate Over Roster Expansion

With rosters expanding on Monday from 25 active players to a maximum of 40, get
ready for the annual debate about the fairness of that rule. Nothing besides the
designated hitter has been around for so long and inspired so much
consternation.

''I hate that,'' Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said. ''To me, that's stupid. You
should get 26 all year and add two or three at the end, if you want. But it's
too much. The game is played so differently when you've got five left-handers.
It's not right. That's the most important part of the year.''

Promoting extra pitchers from the minors, at least, keeps the better relievers
from having to work mop-up innings in blowouts. In theory, the better relievers
get more rest. Yet managers, especially of winning teams, may not encounter many
games like that, anyway.

''To just think you're going to grab four or five more arms -- well, are they
good?'' Pittsburgh Manager Clint Hurdle asked. ''Can they get outs? Because if
they can't get outs, you're right back to where you started.''

Yet some teams with smaller payrolls, and more imperfections on their rosters,
often favor expanded rosters because they can promote a player with a specialty
skill -- a left-handed pitcher, a slugger off the bench, a pinch-runner. To
them, the cost of a few September call-ups is preferable to the season-long
extra roster spot Girardi prefers.

More realistically, Girardi said, he would advocate a system in which a manager
declares up to three extra players eligible for each game. Those players would
be taken from the maximum of 15 added to the roster Sept. 1, but no more than 28
would be active for any game. But even that is imperfect.

''To me, if the roster should be increased, it should be in April,'' Girardi
said. ''That would get guys a chance to get in shape and built up.''

Ideas like this are often discussed at the general managers' meetings in
November, but changing roster size is not as easy as it might seem.

''There have been times where there's been some consensus among G.M.s,'' Indians
General Manager Chris Antonetti said, adding: ''But when you add on the layering
factor of getting ownership support and then negotiating an equitable
arrangement that the union signs off on as well, it becomes a little more
complicated than just fixing what some people have identified as a problem.''

In other words, while the issue is always a popular source of debate, the safest
bet for an outcome seems to be the status quo.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/sports/baseball/texas-rangers-rise-after-a-tri
p-to-the-woodshed.html

3 Children Among Migrants Crammed Into Bus Are Hospitalized in Austria

BYLINE: By ALISON SMALE; Palko Karasz contributed reporting from London.

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 424 words


VIENNA --  Three small children found crammed into a small van with 23 other
migrants were hospitalized with severe dehydration in northern Austria, narrowly
averting another fatal tragedy for refugees fleeing the Middle East and risking
their lives with smugglers, the police said Saturday.

The police found the children around 4 a.m. Friday after a chase of a suspicious
vehicle spotted near the Austrian-German border near Braunau.

The discovery came less than 24 hours after the Austrian police found 71
decomposing bodies in a truck southeast of Vienna.

The driver of the vehicle intercepted Friday initially ignored the police
appeals to stop, said the police spokesman, David Furtner. Eventually, the
driver stopped, and the police found the 26 refugees.

Five-year-old twin girls and a 6-year-old boy, all from Syria, were in
life-threatening condition and taken immediately to the hospital in Braunau, Mr.
Furtner said. Their conditions have since improved, he said.

The driver, a 29-year-old Romanian, has been arrested, Mr. Furtner said.

The grisly discovery of bodies near Vienna has drawn international attention to
the trafficking business behind the migration of tens of thousands of people
fleeing war and despair in the Middle East, Africa and Asia.

On Saturday, three Bulgarians and one Afghan who are suspects in that fatal
smuggling case appeared in court in Kecskemet, Hungary, and were ordered to
remain in detention pending trial on charges of human trafficking involving
torture and financial gain. Officials would not release their identities, and
provided few details, but said the suspects had picked up the 71 migrants on the
Serbian border.

Ferenc Bicskei, president of the Kecskemet regional court said in a news
conference that the local courts had lately been seeing 25 to 30 human smuggling
cases each month, and that in response sentences would be more severe.

During the past day, the Hungarian police said, they had detained 2,822 people
who crossed the border illegally and started criminal proceedings against 13
smugglers who had tried to drive migrants, crammed in trucks, through the
country.

The migrants found on Friday in the van were from Syria, Bangladesh and
Afghanistan, the Braunau spokesman added. All have declined to apply for asylum
in Austria, saying they want to continue to Germany. This will most likely mean
that they will be sent back to Hungary under European Union rules that state
that migrants should be registered in the first member state they are proved to
have entered.




URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/world/europe/austria-migrants-syria.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              Late Edition - Final

No Shelter From the Storm

BYLINE: By RONDA KAYSEN

SECTION: Section RE; Column 0; Real Estate Desk; ASK REAL ESTATE; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 978 words


Punishment by Canopy

More than two years ago, our landlord removed the canopy in front of our
apartment building because he wanted to make it less comfortable in rain or
strong sunlight for building staff, who were picketing over a labor
disagreement. The issues have been more or less settled, but the canopy has not
been replaced. Our building, which has a mix of rent-stabilized and market-rate
tenants, is in a reasonably upscale neighborhood, and all the other comparable
buildings have canopies in good condition. It is frequently inconvenient,
especially on rainy days, not to have the canopy. Is our landlord under any
legal obligation to restore it?

Midtown East, Manhattan

Your landlord certainly found an odd device to use as a cudgel against
disgruntled employees, since it ultimately reduces the value of his property. A
canopy ''is a service to the building, it creates value for him when he's
renting his apartments,'' said Steven W. Birbach, the president of Vanderbilt
Property Management.

While the market-rate tenants have no leverage here, the rent-regulated ones can
certainly make some noise to get that canopy back.

Depending on when the canopy was installed, striking it could be considered a
reduction of services, entitling rent-regulated tenants to a rent reduction,
according to Dov Treiman, a landlord-tenant lawyer. The tenants should file a
complaint with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which oversees
such apartments. There is no fee.

Once tenants start paying a reduced rent, the landlord may realize the high cost
of his decision. ''When the landlord does the math,'' Mr. Birbach said, ''he'll
quickly install the canopy.''


Dividing an Inheritance

My wife and my brother-in-law have inherited their parents' Brooklyn Heights
brownstone, which, unsurprisingly, is worth a lot of money. My brother-in-law
and his wife have lived in the downstairs apartment for many years and want to
continue living in the house. We have our own house and no interest in moving.
Everyone wants to be fair in dividing the estate. How should we proceed?

Brooklyn Heights, Brooklyn

My advice: Proceed with caution. With a lot of money involved -- as in the case
of a Brooklyn Heights brownstone -- things can turn ugly fast.

''I've never seen a situation like this work out long term,'' said Steven M.
Schanker, an estate and trust lawyer. ''At the very beginning everybody is
huggy-kissy, then things happen.''

Your wife and her brother should sit down and have a serious conversation about
what they want, perhaps with a lawyer present to help guide them through their
options. The simplest solution would be to sell the property, divide the
proceeds and walk away.

But since your brother-in-law has no desire to move, that plan might not fly. If
your brother-in-law has the means -- and your sister is willing to part with the
property -- he could buy her out. If the property has not been appraised
recently, both parties should have it appraised to determine its fair market
value.

If that scenario does not pan out, then the siblings could form a limited
liability company to operate the building. Your brother-in-law and any rental
tenants would pay rent to the L.L.C., which would cover the building's expenses.
Any profits would be divided between the siblings.

To proceed in this way, the siblings should draft an operating agreement that
anticipates issues that could cause conflict. For example, how much rent should
your brother-in-law pay, and would it rise with the market? Who pays for
repairs? And here is a biggie: Whose children inherit the brownstone?
(Eventually, several generations might stake a claim.)

''Even when there is nothing to fight about,'' Mr. Schanker said, ''the families
find something to fight about.''


Who Collects the Security Deposit?

I am a college student living in a market-rate rental with three other
roommates. The tenants who rented the apartment before us paid their security
deposit to the landlord. Now the landlord wants us to pay our security deposit
directly to the previous tenants so he does not have to refund their money. He
says it is easier that way. But the lease says we are supposed to pay the
security deposit directly to the landlord. When our lease is up, our landlord
says the new tenants will pay us our security deposit. I do not like this idea.
Is it legal, even though it contradicts the lease?

Flushing, Queens

Well, this plan would certainly make your landlord's life easier -- he would not
need to cut anyone a check or process any incoming money. But to do it legally,
he would need to get everyone involved to sign on.

''There is nothing necessarily illegal about this situation if all parties --
the landlord, the outgoing tenants and the incoming tenants -- agree in
writing,'' said David E. Frazer, a Manhattan lawyer who represents tenants.

If you pay your security deposit to the outgoing tenants, the landlord would be
obligated to continue to hold the original security deposit in trust for you and
your roommates. He cannot, however, require you to recoup your deposit from
future tenants who do not yet exist.

There are potential complications, which might explain your trepidation. What if
the previous tenants damaged the apartment? Who should deduct damages from their
deposit? What if the tenants who replace you agree to the deal, but write you a
bad check? What recourse would you have?

If you are uncomfortable with this plan, say no. Explain your concerns to the
landlord, telling him that you prefer that he handle the money and that he
follow the terms of the lease. If he insists -- or if you run into trouble
getting your security deposit back at the end of your lease -- file a complaint
with the New York State Attorney General's office, which provides mediation
services for tenants dealing with security deposit issues.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/realestate/dear-landlord-wheres-our-building-c
anopy.html

GRAPHIC: DRAWING (DRAWING BY MICHAEL KOLOMATSKY/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: RENT CONTROL (91%); RENTAL PROPERTY (90%); RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY
(90%); REAL ESTATE (90%); LANDLORD & TENANT LAW (78%); REAL ESTATE VALUATIONS

The Last Strains of Summer

BYLINE: By TAMMY LA GORCE

SECTION: Section NJ; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; ARTS | NEW JERSEY; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1149 words


For fans of live music, the end of summer signals the tapering off of festival
season, not to mention barbecues and beach trips. But in New Jersey, September
is shaping up to be as robust a month for outdoor multi-act concerts as June or
July.

Two new festivals may stave off late-summer melancholy for rock fans. The Food
Truck and Rock Carnival in Clark will bring Slash and the Stone Temple Pilots,
among others, and a lot of food. Its organizer called it '''Wayne's World' with
food trucks'' in a recent phone interview. And Shadow of the City in Asbury Park
will skew younger, with acts including Bleachers and MisterWives. Both events,
like the other festivals listed below, should extend summer's party well beyond
Labor Day.

SEPT. 4-6: DELAWARE VALLEY BLUEGRASS FESTIVAL, WOODSTOWN 302-321-6466;
delawarevalleybluegrass2015.org.

The organizers of the 44th annual event, at the Salem County Fairgrounds, are
not purists. In addition to traditional, Appalachian-style bluegrass, they
occasionally bring in country or Cajun performers. This year is no exception:
Marty Stuart and his band, the Fabulous Superlatives, known better in country
than in bluegrass circles, will be a headliner. Sixteen other acts will play the
festival, which moved to New Jersey from Delaware in the '90s, Carl Goldstein,
its founder and coordinator, said, because ''we just ran out of space.'' Steve
Riley & the Mamou Playboys, a band from Louisiana with Cajun roots, and Hot
Rize, a Colorado four-piece straight-ahead bluegrass band, are among the acts
expected to attract up to 6,000 people from as far as Europe, Mr. Goldstein
said.

Other attractions include a children's stage, jam sessions and a clog-dancing
workshop. Tickets range from $25 for a single-day student pass to $80 for an
adult weekend pass.

SEPT. 6: WILDWOOD BLOCK PARTY & MUSIC FESTIVAL, WILDWOOD 609-729-9000;
wildwoodsnj.com.

This free party presented by the City of Wildwood has been taking place annually
for roughly a decade, but this year's installment is likely to draw a much
bigger crowd for a day of music, crafts, games and rides.

''We normally get around 5,000 people, but this year, with Chubby, we're
expecting up to 10,000,'' said Ben Rose, of the Greater Wildwoods Tourism
Improvement and Development Authority, which sponsors the festival. Chubby is
Chubby Checker, the 1950s rock icon who introduced his seminal ''Twist'' at a
music club in Wildwood 55 years ago. ''We're celebrating his return to Wildwood
this year and expect this to be one of our best festivals yet.''

SEPT. 18-20:  FOOD TRUCK AND ROCK CARNIVAL, CLARK  therockcarnival.com.

''We wanted to put together a festival that celebrates the rock 'n' roll
lifestyle,'' said John D'Esposito of Colts Neck, the creator of this new
four-stage event drawing more than 40 music acts, including Slash, Black Label
Society and Anthrax. ''Jersey is one of the strongest rock 'n' roll markets
around, and we haven't had a festival that caters to that market,'' he said.

Mr. D'Esposito, also the founder of the Bamboozle festival and producer of the
Skate and Surf Festival in Asbury Park, explained that those events represented
pop and punk. ''This is rock 'n' roll, the music I grew up on,'' he said. ''It's
the first festival I've done that a father and son can go to together.'' There
will also be 40 food trucks, a craft beer village, rides and appearances by
professional wrestlers.

''This festival is long overdue, Mr. D'Esposito, who is expecting more than
15,000 guests, said. Admission is free for the beer garden, food truck area and
activities like wrestling, skills games and arcades; live music tickets range
from $39.99 for an adult single-day pass to $249.99 for a weekend V.I.P. pass;
children under 10 are admitted free.

SEPT. 18-19: BOOTS AT THE BEACH, NORTH WILDWOOD 609-770-8839;
bootsatthebeach.com.

This free country-music festival is the first installment of what the Anglesea
Irish Society, the local organization behind it, hopes will become an annual
tradition. A Friday night Bar Hoodang will place country bands and D.J.s in
North Wildwood bars. Activities on Saturday include four bands and craft and
food vendors. Acts include Philbilly, a band known to get a crowd dancing, and
Steel Creek, a ''new country'' cover band from Pennsylvania.

SEPT. 19: SHADOW OF THE CITY, ASBURY PARK shadowofthe.city.

Jack Antonoff, frontman of the chart-topping band Bleachers and a member of the
hit machine Fun., is behind this one-day, one-stage festival at the Stone Pony
Summer Stage. Charli XCX, MisterWives, Cults, the Front Bottoms, How to Dress
Well and Robert DeLong will perform, with Bleachers as the headliner. The title
of the festival reflects Mr. Antonoff's feelings for his home state; he is from
Bergenfield and spent summers at the Jersey Shore near Asbury Park.

''When you grow up 10 miles away from the greatest city in the world, it's like
you're constantly looking in the window of the party,'' Mr. Antonoff said. ''So
much of what I do is based off that -- the songs I write, my entire childhood,
the core of who I am is about that. You have a lot of hope and excitement, but
you always feel slightly less-than.''

To emphasize the New Jersey-ness of the festival, Mr. Antonoff has arranged for
local food trucks, a Weird N.J. pop-up stand and arcade games from the local
pinball museum. Tickets are $59.50.

SEPT. 19: OSPAC JAZZ AND BREW FESTIVAL, WEST ORANGE 973-669-7385; ospac.org.

The Oskar Schindler Performing Arts Center began its annual jazz festival in
2001. In 2013, ''they were reorganizing, so they skipped a year,'' said Susan
Anderson, executive director of the New Jersey Arts Incubator, which took over
the event last year. Now, she said, the festival is offering beer and wine.

Its sloping amphitheater includes an 800-foot stage with enough room for an
18-piece orchestra, Ms. Anderson said. The brew festival is next to a small
lake, but the internationally celebrated lineup of jazz greats is the main draw,
said Robert DeVos, the festival's artistic director.

Included on this year's roster: the Bill Charlap Trio, Oscar Perez and the Dave
Stryker Quartet. Gary Walker of WBGO-FM will be the host of the event. The rain
date is Sept. 20. Tickets are $10.

SEPT. 27: BBQ SHOWDOWN, SOUTH AMBOY855-478-6888; irunnewjersey.com.

The popularity of barbecue competitions accounts for the crowd of 25,000 that
turned up for the inaugural BBQ & Country Music Festival last year, said Diana
St. John, president of the production company iRun New Jersey, which organizes
the free event. ''But country music goes so well with barbecue; people set up
lawn chairs and spent all day listening,'' she said.

Ms. St. John expects more of the same this year. Three bands, including the
bluegrass-leaning Mark Miklos Band from East Brunswick, are on the bill
alongside the food trucks and barbecue vendors.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/nyregion/new-jersey-festivals-offer-jazz-blueg
rass-and-a-chance-to-do-the-twist-again.html

The Gilding of the Gold Coast

BYLINE: By KARIN LIPSON

SECTION: Section LI; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; ARTS | STONY BROOK; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1053 words


Did Otto Hermann Kahn, a banker, financier and arts patron, have a rival Long
Island estate on his mind as he built his own palatial house, Oheka, in
Huntington in 1917?

There's no written evidence of that, said Joshua Ruff, chief curator of the Long
Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages in Stony Brook, where he
has organized the exhibition ''Gilding the Coasts: Art and Design of Long
Island's Great Estates.''

When it comes to the enormously wealthy crowd that created these estates, Mr.
Ruff said that ''you have to look more at their actions than their words.''

So, some actions: About 13 miles west of Oheka was a Roslyn estate, Harbor Hill
(since demolished). One of the largest mansions ever built in the country, it
sat on one of the highest points on Long Island.

When Kahn built Oheka, Mr. Ruff said, he had ''massive amounts of earth''
brought in to elevate the terrain, making Oheka ''the highest point on Long
Island.'' It also was the second-largest private residence in the country at the
time. (The largest was Biltmore, in North Carolina.)

But rivalry was just part of the story of these mansions, which had once been
strung along the Long Island coastline ''in an almost unbroken chain,'' in the
words of an excerpt from a century-old newspaper article mounted on one wall of
the exhibition. ''We're talking about palatial structures that are really meant
to say something about the success of their owners,'' Mr. Ruff said. And what
could better trumpet that success than houses built by the very best architects
and designers and filled with the finest objects, from antique statuary and
baronial furniture down to custom-designed silverware and fireplace tongs?

Once numbering more than 1,000 on Long Island, these estates are mostly gone,
victims of disastrous fires, suburban development or the crippling expense of
maintaining them.

Some of the lavish furnishings and art objects, though, have survived, and a
selection of these, along with architectural renderings, blueprints, archival
photographs and explanatory videos, make up ''Gilding the Coasts.''

But the show isn't intended to document the Gatsbyesque existence of some
heedless millionaires (though it does display a first edition of F. Scott
Fitzgerald's ''The Great Gatsby,'' with its North Shore setting). ''It's not
just the lifestyles of the rich and famous,'' Mr. Ruff said. ''It's much more
the artistic part of the equation.''

That equation was formulated after the Civil War, at the dawn of the Gilded Age.
This is when members of ''the Four Hundred''-- a coterie of mostly old-money
socialites from New York City -- built country pleasure spots on the relatively
accessible South Shore of Long Island, near the Great South Bay.

One of the most dashing among them was the young James Hazen Hyde, heir to an
insurance company fortune, whose commanding, three-quarter-length 1901 portrait
by Théobald Chartran hangs in the exhibition. Was there ever a more ''master of
the universe'' look than the one leveled at us by the handsome 25-year-old?

Hyde was master of the Oaks, in Bay Shore, where he indulged his love of
carriage-driving and the sporting life. Near his portrait stands a carriage --
one of 25 he owned, Mr. Ruff said. Whatever the ostensible professional demands
on Hyde, ''he had ample free time'' to sample his carriages, Mr. Ruff said
wryly. Just four years after this portrait, though, Hyde left the country for
France, under the cloud of a possibly trumped-up financial scandal.

With the heyday of the Gilded Age, estate-building migrated to the North Shore,
later dubbed the ''Gold Coast.'' There, craftsmen like Samuel Yellin, a notable
Philadelphia metalworker, created wondrous decorative additions to the exteriors
and interiors of the mansions.

Among Yellin's commissions for Eagle's Nest, the William K. Vanderbilt II estate
(now the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum) in Centerport, was a weather vane
with a nautical theme, on view in the exhibition. Near its top, a three-masted
ship rides the waves, avidly pursued by a trio of sea monsters.

Yellin and his ilk may be the unsung heroes of the Gold Coast estates, Mr. Ruff
said. ''There were a lot of hands and minds,'' he said, ''and not simply the
ones that normally get the ink.''

One who definitely got the ink was the architect Stanford White, whose firm,
McKim, Mead & White, designed some of the era's most iconic buildings.

At Box Hill, White's home in St. James, he tested out his eclectic,
then-unorthodox approach to interiors. The exhibition, re-creating a portion of
the dining room, displays an Italian walnut bench from about 1700; Asian
copper-and-brass plates on a lotus blossom theme from the mid-19th century;
18th-century majolica plates; and other diverse artifacts, many of which were
part of the original dining room. ''A lesser talent would have created a junk
shop'' from such juxtapositions, Mr. Ruff said. But White saw beyond any
supposed clash of cultures or centuries. For him, Mr. Ruff said, ''it was about
texture, color -- the same things that drove Tiffany.''

That's Louis Comfort Tiffany, the glassmaker and artist. The exhibition's
display on Laurelton Hall, Tiffany's 580-acre estate in the town of Oyster Bay,
includes a couple of Tiffany watercolors (''Arab Scene'' and ''Chinese Market,''
both painted around 1872) that reflect the Middle Eastern and Far Eastern
influences on his work; a lamp and vase featuring his iridescent favrile glass;
decorative artifacts; and paintings by other artists.

Laurelton Hall burned down in 1957, though much of its artwork was saved. (Some
is in the Morse Museum in Winter Park, Fla.; a celebrated loggia is in the
Metropolitan Museum of Art.)

As Mr. Ruff writes in the exhibition catalog, four other Long Island estates,
including Inisfada in North Hills -- once the fourth-largest private house in
America -- have been destroyed in the past five years alone. ''How much loss of
this artistic legacy,'' he asks, ''are we willing to tolerate?''

''Gilding the Coasts: Art and Design of Long Island's Great Estates'' runs
through Oct. 25 at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and
Carriages, 1200 Route 25A, Stony Brook. Symposium on the great estates, Oct. 3.
Information: 631-751-0066; longislandmuseum.org.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/nyregion/precious-objects-from-vanishing-estat
es-on-long-island.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTOS: Clockwise from top left: A pink party dress worn by Christine
Brown Smith, a pink silk gown that belonged to Louise Gallatin Gay and an
evening opera cape that belonged to Garetta Reboul Lawson
a life-size portrait of James Hazen Hyde by Théobald Chartran hanging alongside
Hyde's carriage
a wrought-iron weather vane by Samuel Yellin
 and artifacts from Box Hill, the Stanford White Estate. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY JOHNNY
MILANO FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

(78%); HISTORY (77%); ARCHITECTURAL SERVICES (76%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (75%); ART
HISTORY (72%); INTERIOR DESIGN SERVICES (71%); SUBURBS (50%)

                              Late Edition - Final

Yale Students Campaign for All That Jazz

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ

SECTION: Section CT; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; ARTS | NEW HAVEN; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1020 words


Michael Hoot and his compatriots value their hard-won seats in the Yale Jazz
Ensemble, a Yale University-sponsored big band. So it did not sit well when
Thomas C. Duffy, who as university director of bands had led the ensemble for 34
years, suspended its operations for the coming year -- and possibly beyond --
citing a loss of rehearsal space and a lack of qualified brass players.

''The students I know who played in the band and are involved in jazz were
really let down by that,'' said Mr. Hoot, a saxophonist. But Mr. Hoot, who will
be a junior this year, is not taking the situation lying down. He and his fellow
band members hope to reconstitute the ensemble as a student-led activity, just
one example of what they, along with sympathetic faculty members, are doing to
promote jazz on the New Haven campus.

''Yale can do a better job of jazz studies,'' said Brian Kane, an associate
professor in the music department and an adviser to the student activists.

Mr. Kane, who teaches a course in jazz harmony, is one of two professors in the
music department who regularly teach jazz; a smattering of jazz courses are
offered in other departments. None of those courses offer performance
instruction.

The Yale School of Music, a graduate conservatory, has supported jazz by hiring
Willie Ruff, a scholar and musician who has taught musicology and theory and run
a concert series since 1972. It has also supported Mr. Duffy in his work with
the jazz ensemble, an extracurricular activity. Both Mr. Ruff and Mr. Duffy are
professors in the school of music. But those are the exceptions. ''Our mission
is real clear,'' said Robert Blocker, the dean at the Yale School of Music. ''We
train people in the Western canon and in new music.''

In an attempt to broaden Yale's musical mission, the student activists have
revived a group, the Yale Undergraduate Jazz Collective, and set themselves
ambitious -- some say quixotic -- goals.

''We want to push Yale as a university to ultimately welcome jazz as a
curricular offering alongside classical music in both the music department and
the School of Music,'' said Alexander Dubovoy, a senior and the current
president of the collective.

The collective, he said, has been building a community of like-minded students.
At present, he said, the group's registration list counts about 50 student
musicians, a number that should grow after Thursday, when it recruits freshmen
at a music-filled orientation featuring student-run combos and a jam session.

The event, to be open to the public, will be in the Saybrook Underbrook Theater,
a basement space in a Yale residential college, where the collective hosts about
five meetings a semester that bring together up-and-coming professionals and
students. The collective also stages on-campus minifestivals featuring
established names like the pianists Vijay Iyer and David Hazeltine. Over three
years, the festivals have doubled annual attendance to 600.

Translating such numbers into course changes is another story. Mr. Dubovoy said
his plans for the school year might include lobbying for a certificate in jazz
studies, drawing on elements of the program at Princeton, where students qualify
after completing four related courses, taking part in educational outreach and
performing in one of the music department's jazz groups.

But Yale does not offer classes in jazz performance. With the suspension of the
jazz ensemble, it does not sponsor extracurricular jazz bands. Nor does it offer
lessons for credit with practitioners of the jazz repertory, though qualified
undergraduates can take lessons with classical musicians through the School of
Music.

Studying through the School of Music is ''something I personally would love to
do,'' said Mr. Hoot, the incoming president of the collective.

''That's tough for jazz since the graduate school is so classically oriented,''
he said. ''I'm a saxophone player, but the School of Music doesn't even have a
sax teacher.''

Mr. Blocker said that hiring a saxophone teacher had been discussed, but that
discussions focused more on finding a teacher who specialized in the classical
repertory. ''A teacher who teaches that,'' he said, ''is not likely to be the
teacher who's going to be teaching or talking about the performance practices of
John Coltrane.''

Given the entrenched structure for resource allocation at Yale, Mr. Duffy said
it was ''highly unlikely'' that the collective would achieve its curriculum
goals through lobbying. He suggested that the students start by signing up for
the music department's course in chamber music performance. ''The department
would have to adjudicate whether they want chamber music credit to be given to
jazz groups,'' he said.

Whatever tack the students take on curriculum matters, he said, would be
separate from his deliberations on the jazz ensemble, whose fate as a
university-sponsored endeavor he will be exploring while the renovation of
Hendrie Hall, where the band had rehearsed, was being completed. That has been
scheduled for next year.

He said he had encountered a shortage of qualified trombone and trumpet
students, a situation he observed at other Ivy League schools trying to muster a
big band. While he offered to lend music to the collective as it tried to
reconstitute the jazz ensemble, he said he would be ''stunned'' if they could
sustain 17 top-flight section players throughout the year.

Mr. Hoot acknowledged the ''immense amount of work'' that would be required.
Nonetheless, he can find some precedent for success in the history of
entrepreneurial big bands at Yale; in earlier decades, the bands landed dates on
New York City stages and even recording contracts -- a history Mr. Ruff said
today's collective was embracing. ''I'm having the time of my life,'' he said,
''watching them trying to recreate at least an appreciation for the music that
drove all this.''

The Yale Undergraduate Jazz Collective Freshman Welcome Concert is at 7 p.m. on
Sept. 3, Saybrook Underbrook Theater, 242 Elm Street, New Haven. Free admission.
Information: 608-320-6092 or yale.edu/jazzcollective.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/nyregion/yale-students-campaign-for-all-that-j
azz.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTOS: A jam session on the Old Campus by members of the Yale
Undergraduate Jazz Collective included Alexander Dubovoy on keyboard (also,
below left), Sam Frampton on guitar, Jake Backer on bass and Michael Hoot on
saxophone. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY WILL GEARTY)

Tumultuous Time for Two Regions

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; ART; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 174 words


It's always interesting to learn what a rich, acquisitive institution like the
Museum of Modern Art has added to its collection. The latest report is the
exhibition ''Transmissions: Art in Eastern Europe and Latin America,
1960-1980,'' which opens on September 5 and will present some 300 artworks in
numerous mediums, many on view for the first time. Nearly all date from around
1968, a period when art radically diversified, sometimes dematerializing
altogether. These works represent artists from distant regions whose efforts ran
parallel in terms of strategies (largely Conceptual, frequently
performance-oriented), political contexts (often oppressive) and interests
(protest, mass media, popular art). Some names -- Valie Export, Ana Mendieta,
Edward Krasinski, Juan Downey, Fernando Botero -- will be familiar; others will
be much less so. The show will surely reflect the MoMA's desire for a broad
global reach, but perhaps also the aesthetic narrowness of its relentless
elevation of Conceptual-oriented work. (Through Jan. 3, moma.org.)

URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/arts/design/moma-presents-an-exhibition-on-eas
tern-european-and-latin-american-art.html

Juan Downey's ''Map of America.'' (PHOTOGRAPHS BY MARISOL ESCOBAR
 JUAN DOWNEY/ARTISTS RIGHTS SOCIETY (ARS), NEW YORK, VIA THE MUSEUM OF MODERN
ART, NEW YORK)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

(88%)
