                              Late Edition - Final

Speculators Rush In

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2182 words


More than 150 years ago, Manifest Destiny drove American pioneers westward. A
horde of speculators and moguls staked claim to everything before them as they
pressed onward to the Pacific, their mission being to ''overspread the continent
allotted by Providence for the free development of our yearly multiplying
millions,'' as the journalist John L. O'Sullivan wrote in 1845.

The last year has seen a form of reverse and truncated manifest destiny, as a
new horde of speculators (moguls, nightclub impresarios and their yearly
multiplying conspicuous consumers) drives and flies ever eastward from Manhattan
toward that beguiling jewel of Long Island, the Hamptons.

Where their predecessors came on horseback and covered wagons, this modern breed
travels by helicopter, black S.U.V., Land Rover and Porsche. As with its
antecedent, the migration has its impediments, in the form of local laws,
citizen groups and politicians fighting to protect ''the heart and soul of this
community,'' as Larry Cantwell, the East Hampton town supervisor, put it in an
interview this month.

But where those who headed west during the frontier days overcame their
obstacles with strong horses, big guns and sheer brawn, this new Hamptons breed
is seeking to do so with strong lawyers, big political and public relations guns
and sheer financial brawn.

There seem to be two driving factors behind this Hamptons version of manifest
destiny: money and the drive to make boatloads of it, and money, the compulsion
to spend boatloads of it accumulated, apparently, after so many years of
generous Wall Street bonuses and (at least until now) sizable stock gains.

And then there is that American will to leave one's mark on God's exquisite
canvas, even if it means inexorably changing it.

This push is a big part of why the Hamptons have been so particularly chaotic
this summer, as a gold-rush mentality has combined with a determined
expansionism to transform sleepy enclaves of the East End into redoubts of
McMansions or unrecognizable party zones.

Yes, the Hamptons have long been home to big money and willful players. And the
complaint that the place is becoming overrun has been lodged for a few years.
But throughout the eastern hamlets, most acutely in Montauk, there is an
overwhelming sense among longtime residents and visitors that this summer the
whole dynamic hit a long predicted inflection point.

It could be seen in July, when hundreds of citizens showed up at an East Hampton
town meeting to demand the local officials do more to rein in the nightly chaos
caused by the booming Montauk party scene.

It could be seen two weeks ago when the Federal Railroad Administration warned
the Long Island Rail Road about potentially dangerous crowding on its most
popular Hamptons-bound train.

And it can be seen weekly in the local newspapers, like The Southampton Press,
where the architect Preston T. Phillips recently wrote a column declaring the
area was suffering from an illness whose symptoms include: ''unrelenting scourge
of aircraft of every description, traffic congestion beyond anyone's concept of
a bucolic existence, and the general feeling between locals and second-home
owners alike that the long-held concepts of fairness, politesse, largess, and
noblesse oblige have given way to arrogance, personal gain at the expense of
others, one-upmanship and ostentation.''

Even David E. Rattray, who has seen it all as the third generation of his family
to edit The East Hampton Star, thinks this year has brought something different.

''Every summer you say, 'Oh my God, it's more crowded than it's ever been
before.' The difference this summer is it's taken on a real feeling that people
are just appalled,'' he said. ''The scale of the reaction is new, and I think it
reflects some really amorphous tipping point.''

In places like Sag Harbor Village, Southampton Village and East Hampton Village,
the aforementioned spirit is evidencing itself in the will to build ever-bigger
and more imposing buildings -- witness the new $45-million spec house in
Southampton called Twin Peaks -- which has led officials in all three places to
consider placing new size limits on residential construction.

After East Hampton Village went ahead and did so this summer, a couple of
residents, including the Giuliani administration planning director Joseph B.
Rose, filed suit to block them.

Mr. Rose said in an interview that he was ''completely supportive of regulations
that protect the village and stop oversize houses being developed on smaller
lots,'' but that the regulations were ''ill-conceived'' and would prove
counterproductive.

Yet most of the action stems from the unimpeded growth in the summer population,
which, The East Hampton Star reported, had increased 30 percent from 2000 to
2010 -- the last year for which Suffolk County has solid estimates -- to about
262,000.

And that was before the financial recovery kicked in: Hurricane Sandy sent
Jersey Shore goers to seek out undamaged beaches in Long Island and Airbnb
created hundreds of effective (and, in many cases, illegal) guest rooms. Another
data set, Long Island Rail Road figures, show ridership on its Montauk Line is
up about 10 percent since 2012, or by 66,000.

The swelling of the population is to this version of manifest destiny what gold
was to so many who were inspired by the first one: an opportunity to hit it big.
That has, in turn, caused more new businesses to open, many of them apparently
viewing potential code violations as a cost of doing business; more local mom
and pops to sell to outsiders for many millions of dollars, many of them to
financial industry titans teamed with big city club promoters, and ever more
visitors to pour in to enjoy the bacchanalian offerings of the new
establishments.

Any manifest-destiny-like movement has to start with a burning desire to head to
the place of conquest. Among those capitalizing on the urge is a new crop of
charter-plane and technology-enabled helicopter services like Gotham Air and
Blade. The air services allow customers to book 35-minute, one-way
Manhattan-to-East End flights (for $500 and up) on their smartphones.

This service has delighted those like the actor Jon Hamm and the model Anita
Hodosi. But it is driving to distraction the locals and second-home owners stuck
below the flight path, and whose airport-related noise complaints spiked to more
than 400 percent last summer as, the town reports, helicopter flights increased
nearly 50 percent. The town government responded this year by limiting when and
how often the flights could take off and land.

But the services are determined. A group called Friends of the East Hampton
Airport, whose membership includes aviation interests, quickly formed to file
lawsuits to stop the changes, succeeding in at least temporarily blocking the
most stringent of them.

To help make its case publicly, the group has enlisted the powerhouse political
firm SKDKnickerbocker, whose officials have factored in the presidential
campaigns of John Kerry and Barack Obama and the successful effort to redevelop
the Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn over community opposition there. They have
disputed the town's figures on takeoffs and landings and questioned the size of
the opposition.

Loren Riegelhaupt, a Manhattan-based SKDKnickerbocker executive who acts as a
Friends of the East Hampton Airport spokesman, said, ''We remain deeply
committed to working with the local communities to understand how we can be
better neighbors.''

Kathleen Cunningham, chairwoman of a neighborhood group calling itself the Quiet
Skies Coalition, said, ''They're definitely playing hardball.''

But none have felt the effects more than those who live in Montauk, the hamlet
at the trail's very end. The overwhelming success of new-style night-life spots
there like the Surf Lodge and the Sloppy Tuna -- both of which have big
investors as co-owners and have been hit with numerous town violations over the
years -- has enticed others to follow their lead.

In only the last 18 months, four major transactions have taken place.

The private equity mogul Marc Rowan has bought the bayside lobster takeout shack
Duryea's from the family that founded it some 80 years ago (price: $6.3
million).

The New York-based real estate developer Jon Krasner and a local partner, Beau
Campsey, have bought the Shagwong restaurant and bar owned by local favorite
Jimmy Hewitt for nearly 50 years ($2.6 million). They took over the lease for
the nearby space that housed O'Murphy's Pub for nearly 25 years, for an
undisclosed sum O'Murphy's could not afford (O'Murphy's found new digs a couple
of miles away).

The nightclub magnate Sean MacPherson bought a defunct hotel in the middle of
the residential area of Ditch Plains ($1.15 million).

The Australian restaurateur and club promoter James Willis and a partner, the
corporate lawyer Robert Hirsh, took over the harbor side restaurant the
Cross-Eyed Clam (which sold this year for $2.85 million).

The ambitions of these investors do not always stop at the limits of town
zoning. For instance, Mr. Rowan submitted conceptual plans for Duryea's this
year that would knock down the iconic shack and replace it with a
6,350-square-foot restaurant. The space is effectively zoned for a seafood store
and takeout counter. He also plans to destroy the Duryea family home across the
narrow street to make way for a large parking lot, which is literally a Joni
Mitchell song. The town has asked Mr. Rowan to reconsider his plans, and he says
he is doing so.

Mr. Rowan, who has a home in Southampton, said he had fallen in love with the
area's natural beauty on bike rides through Montauk and that he would work with
the town to retain Duryea's original spirit.

''I'm very sympathetic to what they're going through out there,'' he said. ''Any
community in the midst of change has to be concerned about change and managing
the change.''

Town officials contend that Mr. Willis and Mr. Hirsh did not seek their
permission this season when they created another new Montauk draw by renaming
the Cross-Eyed Clam (calling it Harbor),  exceeding its 68-seat capacity by well
over 200 people and introducing dancing and musical acts, including the rapper
Ja Rule, even though they did not have approval to operate as a nightclub.

The perceived mercenary sensibility of some of the newer establishments (which
is not shared by locally grown favorites like the Montauk Brewing Company) has
proved jarring even to some of the community's stalwart business leaders.

''My parents came here to make a living -- I was born here, raised here
K-through-high school, became part of the community, part of my church,
president of the Kiwanis,'' said Henry Uihlein, whose family has run a marina,
boat rental and motel for more than five decades. Now, he said, in many cases,
''you got people buying here to make a buck and to invest with no regard for
infrastructure or quality of life. All they see is, Montauk has money now.''

That sense, building for several years, finally boiled over after the July 4
holiday, when the throngs of rowdy clubgoers left a trash-strewn wake of beer
cans, red Solo cups and an abundance of post-weekend anecdotes about public
urination, (illegally) packed share houses and, as The New York Post reported in
July, public fornication.

That is what prompted several hundred incensed citizens, including firefighters,
fishermen, chamber of commerce members, year-rounders and second-home owners as
well, to descended upon the monthly meeting at the Montauk Firehouse, usually
attended by a few dozen at most, to beg the town to do something.

''In the 50 years I've been attending board meetings, I've never seen anything
like it,'' said Richard D. Kahn, a Montauk resident and board member of the
group Concerned Citizens of Montauk.

''We have to find positive ways to move forward and reclaim our Montauk,'' said
Diane Hausman, chairwoman of Montauk's advisory committee to the town board.
''We're not going to do that by catering to party animals coming in here to take
over and disrespect everything that we love so much.''

Mr. Cantwell, the town board and local police have responded by winning a
temporary injunction keeping Harbor from operating as a nightclub; stepping up
enforcement against illegal share houses, and bringing noise violations against
nightclubs including the Sloppy Tuna, whose name is a form of onomatopoeia.

''All of this stuff is not bad -- if you can afford to take a helicopter from
New York, God bless you,'' Mr. Cantwell said. ''Whether it's helicopter
companies or young people going over the top partying, don't tread on the
community, do it in a way that is not a nuisance to others, that's the
message.''

But manifest destiny is a powerful thing. Even after the judge's injunction,
Harbor continued to draw violations, officials said. And an owner of the Sloppy
Tuna has responded in another way, by filing a lawsuit calling the violations
unfair and charging local officials have ''exceeded the limits of government
authority.''




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/fashion/the-battle-for-the-soul-of-the-hampton
s.html

something about rowdy clubgoers. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY YANA PASKOVA FOR THE NEW YORK

                              Late Edition - Final

For Brides, the Crop Top Brings Its Own Challenges

BYLINE: By SHEILA MARIKAR

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; FIELD NOTES; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 937 words


When Cammy Hébert began planning her May wedding to Nick Miller, she knew a
froufrougown would not do. Visions of Emilio Pucci danced in her head:
specifically, a photo she came across years ago, in which a model wore a tight
short-sleeved crop top and a long skirt reminiscent of a bunch of doilies.

''People are finally doing more and more skirts, but they're still doing them
with those bedazzled corsets, which is so not my look,'' said Ms. Hébert, 29, a
founder of the Los Angeles-based clothing line Show Me Your Mumu.

She conceived of her own two-piece wedding dress with the bridal designer
Watters: a ''princess fun skirt'' paired with a simple cropped tank top, ''sort
of reminiscent of Calvin Klein in the '90s, that cuts in so you can see my
shoulders,'' she said. And, crop tops being what they are, also showing her
midsection.

''I'm not in shape enough to be in a crop top in front of 300 people yet,'' Ms.
Hébert said. ''I'm on my way.''

Michelle Obama arms, take a back seat. The trend of midriff-exposing tops has
entered the bridal department, possibly adding a whole new element of angst for
those who dare to bare quite a bit more than most traditions dictate. (Though in
some traditions, like those of India, brides have worn midsection-revealing
saris and lenghas for centuries.)

With waist-cinchers out of the question for midriff-baring brides, working out
is all but a must. Ms. Hébert has increased her Lagree-style Pilates regimen to
three classes a week, which she takes at the Studio (MDR) in Marina del Rey,
Calif., under the tutelage of her future sister-in-law, Mary Miller. ''It's a
love-hate relationship right now,'' Ms. Miller said.

The method of Pilates that Ms. Miller teaches includes cardiovascular exercises,
which increases calorie burn. ''You're going to get that heart rate up, you're
going to start sweating,'' she said.

And, Ms. Hébert, said, ''It gets these weird little small stomach muscles that
you didn't even know you had.''

Spinning is also a favored calorie burner. Fiona Gibb, 41, took classes at
SoulCycle and Karen Lord Pilates Movement in TriBeCa in anticipation of her Aug.
8 wedding.

''I do a lot of oblique things, oblique presses on the bike,'' said Nicholas
Wagner, a SoulCycle instructor who regularly sees Ms. Gibb on a bike at 7 a.m.
''We do a lot of stabilizing exercises to keep your core engaged.''

But exercise alone does not ensure a flat stomach.

Ms. Hébert is cutting out one caloric vice a month in the run-up to her wedding
(gone already: pizza, chips and French fries). Ms. Gibb planned to exercise
restraint even after the vows, or at least until her photographer packed up.

''When you're actually wearing the crop top, it's not like you can get there and
stuff your face all night,'' she said. ''There are considerations to be made.''

One key to flaunting the crop top is simply being body-confident to begin with.
''I always love working out,'' said Rebecca Brown, 33, who ran and took boot
camp and Pilates classes in the months leading up to her wedding. ''I'd say I
paid a little more attention to my obliques but I didn't really do anything that
different.'' It was a continuation of her normal routine, she added.

Sheena Patel, 30, who is wearing a midriff-revealing lengha for her Oct. 24
wedding reception, said her routine involves situps and planks. A lot of planks.

''I didn't even realize there were so many things you can do with planks,'' she
said.

Why not zip into something buttressed with boning, have cake, and eat it, too?
Crop-top-preferring brides pass on that idea.

''Dresses are really boring,'' said Ms. Brown, who wore a secondhand tulle
skirt, a sequined Alice & Olivia crop top and a pair of personalized Air Jordan
sneakers for her May 23 wedding in Sonoma, Calif. ''My favorite type of outfit
is drop-crotch trousers and a crop top. This just felt like an extension of
that, as opposed to being stuffed up in a dress.''

Designers have caught on. Reem Acra paired a rib-grazing lace blouse with a
flowing skirt in its fall 2015 bridal collection, and Theia debuted a tube
top/crop top double threat at its spring 2016 show. For her wedding, Ms. Gibb
wore a silk crepe pencil skirt and bell-sleeve top from the New York-based label
Houghton.

''They make the pieces custom and I said, 'Don't make the crop top too short,
I'm not a 19-year-old model,' '' she said. ''For me, it was just a slight gap
between the pieces.''

Houghton has pushed the envelope with some of its other bohemian-punk designs,
including a cape that reveals the better part of the wearer's chest and an
asymmetrical skirt that, in the front, hits well above the knee. (Grooms looking
to make a statement, take note: They also offer drop-crotch dress pants.)

Crop tops, the Houghton designer Katharine Polk argued, can be chaste.

''It's not like you're walking down the aisle in a bikini,'' she said. ''Showing
a lot of cleavage with a sweetheart neckline could be way more offensive.''

Not everyone sees it that way. ''There were definitely family members that
thought it was way too casual, way too weird,'' Ms. Brown said. ''But my mom got
married in a suit, so she totally gets me.''

Yet these brides don't foresee their bare midsection being the thing they
remember most about their big day. The working out, the dieting and any sturm
und drang about showing their waistline sometimes gets sidelined by other
wedding-day must-haves, contradictory as they may seem.

''I want a queso fountain at my wedding,'' Ms. Hébert said.

Read more: Two-Piece Wedding Dresses Make Their Statement

Before Coming Together, Separates




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/fashion/weddings/defying-tradition-and-working
-out-to-wear-bridal-crop-tops.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTOS: Top, Cammy Hébert at her bridal fitting in Los Angeles. Above,
Ms. Hébert, in preparation for her crop-top wedding gown, has been doing
workouts that focus on her abdominal muscles. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY ELIZABETH LIPPMAN
FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

                               The New York Times

                             August 30, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Charles Compton, John Koss

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Society Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 204 words


Charles Hutchens Compton and John Bade Koss were married Friday at the Union
Club, a private club in Boston. Maura Healey, the Massachusetts attorney
general, received permission from the state to officiate.

Mr. Compton (left), 36, is a finance project leader in Boston for the Boston
Consulting Group. He graduated from Wake Forest and received an M.B.A. from
Vanderbilt. He also received a master's degree in supply chain management from
Penn State.

He is a son of Rebecca Hutchens Compton and James E. Compton of Greensboro, N.C.
His father works in Greensboro as a first vice president for investments at
Davenport & Company, an investment firm based in Richmond, Va.

Mr. Koss, 35, is a director in the Boston office of Counsel on Call, a Nashville
legal services firm. He heads the firm's client and attorney relations teams for
the Northeast. He graduated from Northwestern, from which he also received a
master's degree in journalism. He received a law degree from Boston University.

He is a son of Dr. Mary P. Koss and Dr. Paul G. Koss of Tucson. His mother is a
professor of family and community medicine at the University of Arizona. His
father practices internal medicine with Northwest Allied Physicians in Tucson.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/fashion/weddings/charles-compton-john-koss.htm
l

GRAPHIC: PHOTO (PHOTOGRAPH BY LISA NEIGHBORS)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: GRADUATE & PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS (90%); FAMILY (78%); LAW SCHOOLS (77%);
LEGAL SERVICES (77%); WEDDINGS & ENGAGEMENTS (73%); CONSULTING SERVICES (72%);
SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT (70%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (66%); FAMILY
PRACTICE (65%); INTERNAL MEDICINE (64%)

ORGANIZATION: BOSTON UNIVERSITY (94%); UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA (55%)

CUSTOM COMPUTER PROGRAMMING SERVICES (58%)

                               The New York Times

                             August 30, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

China Proves Golden for Met

BYLINE: By VANESSA FRIEDMAN

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Style Desk; CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1238 words


The talk of Wall Street over the last week may have been Shanghai's plunging
stock market, but many blocks farther uptown, where commuter traffic gives way
to verdant sidewalks, a different set of numbers related to China was making
news. As it entered its final week, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's spring
Costume Institute show, ''China: Through the Looking Glass,'' was attaining
blockbuster status.

As of last Friday morning, 735,000 people had attended the show, with a week to
go before its close on Sept. 7, including a final Friday and Saturday with
viewing hours extended until midnight. That has already made it the most-visited
Costume Institute show in the museum's history, displacing ''Alexander McQueen:
Savage Beauty,'' which pulled in 661,509 attendees, as well as elevating it to
No. 7 -- and climbing -- on the museum's top-10 most popular list, on a par with
other 700,000-plus-visitor shows such as the ''Mona Lisa'' (1963), ''Origins of
Impressionism'' (1995) and ''Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art'' (2010).

Andrew Bolton, curator at the Costume Institute and the man behind the show,
said there have been more positive responses left in the visitor's comment box
than ever before. (''Usually people use it as an opportunity to vent
displeasure,'' he said. ''Often at the lighting, or the signage.'')

By any objective measure, this will be the most successful fashion show the Met
has ever had. The question is: Why?

''Honestly, it totally surprised me,'' Mr. Bolton said. ''I was prepared for it
to be polarizing. We were predicting around 500,000 visitors. I never expected
this level of response. ''

''No one expected it would surpass McQueen,'' said Maxwell K. Hearn, the Douglas
Dillon chairman of the department of Asian art, and Mr. Bolton's collaborator on
the exhibition, which is in the Asian art galleries on the second floor, some
Egyptian galleries on the first floor and the Anna Wintour Costume Center on
ground level.

I didn't expect it, either. Not because I didn't like the show (it's visually
engrossing in its mix of luxury, whimsy and point) but because it doesn't have
the single iconic hook that can transform a purportedly high culture meditation
into an extended pop culture moment.

After all, it isn't, as Mr. Bolton said, immediately obvious from the name what
the show is about. (Answer: the way a received fantasy version of China engages
the imaginations of Western designers.) And the subject itself was ripe for
criticism from those who thought the approach played to a now-discredited
stereotype of the East. You can't attribute it to the sheer size of the
exhibition, the largest ever, or it's length, because size does not equate to
allure.

There wasn't the sort of human gossip element that helped drive interest in the
McQueen show, held a year after the designer's suicide and days after Kate
Middleton married Prince William in a dress by Sarah Burton for Alexander
McQueen.

There was, to be fair, lots of striking use of mixed media, which made it seem
both very contemporary as well as historic. And it included film -- Wong
Kar-wai, who wrote and directed ''In the Mood for Love,'' was the exhibit's art
director, and clips from movies like ''The Last Emperor'' and ''The World of
Suzie Wong'' abound -- always a popular medium.

But Mr. Wong is an independent director as opposed to a household name, and when
Baz Luhrmann, a much more recognizable Hollywood figure, was the creative
consultant on an earlier Costume Institute show, 2012's ''Schiaparelli and
Prada: Impossible Conversations,'' it wasn't nearly the same hot ticket.

When I first saw the show in May, I was struck by the facile nature of the
fashion when juxtaposed against the antiquities. No matter the clothes' beauty
-- I remember the runway impact of Tom Ford's pagoda collection for Yves Saint
Laurent and being amazed by the broken blue and white china shards of porcelain
on an Alexander McQueen bodice -- they pale when compared with the source of the
inspiration, in part because the latter has a creative integrity the former only
borrows. Often too literally.

It's a good thing for the Asian art, because it makes you look twice at what
otherwise may have been background pottery, for example, but not necessarily the
clothes. It's no accident my favorite room is the ''small Buddha room,'' which
features an enormous gold dress by Guo Pei, the Chinese designer who made
Rihanna's yellow egg-yolk cape for the opening gala, surrounded by multiple
earthen Buddhas. The connection being one of silhouette and shade as opposed to
anything overt.

This probably has more to do with my own discomfort with what the exhibit
revealed about the superficiality of the fashion imagination rather than the
exhibition itself (indeed, it's part of the point of the show); as Holland
Cotter wrote in his review, ''the difference between the two disciplines is, too
often, made glaring.''

It turns out reviews have nothing on word of mouth as an audience-driver. ''I
call it the 'Harry Potter' effect,'' Mr. Bolton said.

And the word ''China'' was magical. Mr. Hearn said, ''Chinese visitors often
want to see how China is presented in Western museums.'' Forty percent of the
show's visitors have been international, and since June, 14 percent of total
international visitors have been Chinese, the Met's largest single group of
overseas visitors. China was also, until recently, the one of the most lucrative
markets for Western fashion designers.

Indeed, when the cynic in me first heard the exhibition's title, I wondered if
it was a calculated move to capture some of that gold dust. When pressed, Mr.
Bolton claimed ''we never think about the numbers,'' though he did say, ''I want
to do exhibits that are relevant and resonate in contemporary culture.'' It's a
slightly specious distinction (is making a listicle resonating with the culture
or catering to click bait? Is there a difference?), but when it comes to the
latter, there's no question that China has been the buzz of many conversations,
in every sector from Hollywood to finance, travel to e-commerce.

In any case, the museum quickly learned that its original expectations were
going to be surpassed, and in late June, Thomas P. Campbell, the director and
chief executive of the Met, decided to extend the show another three weeks. It
was only the second time a Costume Institute show had been extended (McQueen set
that precedent).

''We are like a fungal infection,'' Mr. Bolton said. ''We start out small, and
take over the whole museum.''

This kind of takeover has created another problem for its creator: follow-up.

Mr. Bolton acknowledged the challenge, noting that, after McQueen, in order to
better manage expectations, he and Harold Koda curated two much ''quieter, more
poetic'' shows: one based on a conversation between two women (Schiaparelli and
Prada) and one that took a forensic approach to the work of Charles James.

That said, however, Mr. Bolton has an ambitious wish list. He'd like to do a
conversation between Edith Wharton and Henry James inspired by two portraits in
the American galleries that would combine an examination of the American men's
wear tradition with furniture and sound. He would really like to work with the
Egyptian galleries.

The museum's biggest show, after all, was 1979's ''Treasures of Tutankhamun,''
which attracted over a million people. You do the math.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/fashion/nyc-museum-met-exhibition-china-and-fa
shion-proves-golden.html

Megan Janine Calhoun and Max Rosenblum Broude were married Saturday evening at

Ministries for the event. The bride's brother, Jay S. Calhoun, led the ceremony,
including Jewish prayers, the exchange of vows and the breaking of the glass.

The bride, 27, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a senior

degrees from the University of Southern California, one in social work and the
other in gerontology. She is the daughter of Linda J. Calhoun and Zan F. Calhoun
of Rolling Hills, Calif.

The groom, 30, works in Beverly Hills, Calif., as the manager of comedy
development at the Hurwitz Company, a television production company. He
graduated from Yale, and is the son of Judy A. Rosenblum and John S. Broude of
Fort Worth.

Tanya Jazmin Brammer, the daughter of Maryann V. Nacianceno of Mission, Tex.,
and Artemio C. Brammer of McAllen, Tex., was married Saturday evening to Aaron
Michael Perlmutter, a son of Sandra L. Perlmutter and Dr. Dan M. Perlmutter of
Corona del Mar, Calif. Rabbi Richard Steinberg officiated at Terranea Resort in
Palos Verdes, Calif.

Mrs. Perlmutter, 28, is a production assistant for handbags and other items in
the Los Angeles design studio of Bebe, the women's clothing brand and retail
chain that has its headquarters in Brisbane, Calif. She graduated from Concordia
University in Irvine, Calif.

Her father is a letter carrier for the United States Postal Service in McAllen.
He is also a retired Air Force staff sergeant who was last stationed at Cannon
Air Force Base in Clovis, N.M. Her mother is a material planner, assisting in
the acquisition of parts and services for maintenance, in the aerospace division

Brammer and of Felipe Nacianceno.

Hills, Calif. He graduated from Duke and received an M.B.A. from Northwestern.

His father, a retired dentist, is the founder and chairman of DMP Properties, a
real estate investment firm in Newport Beach, Calif.

                              Late Edition - Final

Hung by a Thread

BYLINE: By JUDITH NEWMAN

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Style Desk; CULTURAL STUDIES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1440 words


Every new technology is amazing, and every new technology brings its own
horrors. For example, there was no such thing as waking up at 30,000 feet on the
shoulder of a stranger who is covered in your drool until we invented commercial
air flight (and Ambien).

And so it is with one small email ''feature'' that we cannot do without, yet has
cost almost everyone who has ever texted or emailed a moment of heart-stopping
panic. I'm speaking of auto-fill.

It is often confused with auto-correct. Here's the difference: Auto-fill fills
in names and information based on just a few keystrokes; auto-correct does, too,
but it also corrects (and predicts) writing in the body of a note.

For example, if I want to write to my editor Didi Gluck, I type 'Didi'' in an
email and auto-fill gives me the rest; If I am writing her name in a text to
someone, well, other things may happen. ''Did you know 'Didi' auto-corrects to
'dildo'? Because I do,'' Ms. Gluck told me, cheerfully.

In some ways auto-fill may be the more problematic function, leading to not just
semantic misunderstandings but to entire passels of information being dispatched
to the wrong people. Secrets are disclosed, petty true feelings are revealed,
words (and, worse, photos) of longing and lust end up in the email box of your
boss instead of your lover. And no one is immune.

Several months ago Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York complained in an email to a
few staff members that taking one of those I'm-a-man-of-the-people subway rides
to an event had made him late. The mayor mistakenly included on this grumpy
email thread Michael Powell, a reporter for The New York Times who for years
covered city hall.

The result? A perhaps unwelcome article about the mayor's chronic lateness. ''I
almost deleted his email because the sender only identified himself as 'B,' ''
Mr. Powell said. ''That struck me as suspicious, like perhaps it was one of
those Nigerian or Croatian bankers with a grand idea, if only I'd send my bank
account number.''

Slips like these remind us that Sigourney Weaver -- No, wait, I mean Sigmund
Freud -- is alive and well and living in our keyboards. Just consider how
frequently we send emails to precisely the person who should never ever receive
them. It's sending your estimated yearly tax income to an old frenemy, who has a
similar name to your accountant; it's getting out the word to friends that you
need a new job and including your boss on that thread.

For Britt Kazmac, a New York City tutor, it was the all-too-common erotic
message debacle. ''I thought I was sexting my husband,'' she said of her now
ex-husband, ''and he was playing coy by responding with texts like, 'Why are you
sending these to me?' Then I looked more closely, and realize I had been sexting
my daughter's Charismatic Christian babysitter.''

Ms. Kazmac believes she has a gift for this type of spectacular misfire. ''After
a bad third date I wrote to my best friend, Donna: 'What a waste of a bikini
wax,' '' she said, adding to the update, ''Worst sex ever.' It would have been
nice if her best friend had received it; instead it went to the only other Donna
in her address book: her graduate-school professor.

Or take this cautionary tale from David Hirshey, an editor at HarperCollins. Mr.
Hirshey had paid seven figures for a celebrity memoir, and was getting constant
interference from the celebrity's manager. In a moment of desperation and
frustration he sent out an email to his colleagues with the heading A Few Wise
Words from <X's> Brain-Dead Manager. One of his colleagues and the manager
shared the same unusual last name, and guess which one ended up on the email?

''Two minutes after I sent this, my phone rang and I heard the person on the
other end say, 'Please hold for <X's> brain-dead manager,' '' Mr. Hirshey said.
''Needless to say, this woman was not amused and made the rest of the publishing
process a living hell for me.''

Even if we become more cautious in our day-to-day emailing, we sometimes forget
how auto-fill works in programs we use less regularly. We're not quite paying
attention to the rules, as Laurie Lewis, a real estate broker with the Corcoran
Group, found out recently when she joined LinkedIn.

''LinkedIn 'asks permission' to access your address book,'' Ms. Lewis said. ''I
said yes. And then, unbeknown to me, it automatically selects everyone.'' She
ended up sending a request to everyone she had ever known, ''including and
especially people that I would literally cross a street to avoid.''

''LinkedIn auto-filled my worst mistakes,'' Ms. Lewis said, ''and reconnected me
with all of them.''

There is a flip side to auto-fill, when we are not the perpetrators of a gaffe
but the unwitting participants, caught in email chains we have absolutely no
business being in.

''This happens a lot if you have a really common name like Ann,'' said the
writer Ann Leary, who has borne gleeful and illegitimate witness to various
high-stakes real estate deals and publishing negotiations. Recently Ms. Leary
found herself in the family reunion and potluck planning roundelay of a famous
actress she barely knew. (This happens occasionally; Ann's husband is the
comedian and actor Denis Leary.)

A beauty known for playing chief executive officers, presidents and other
powerful women, the actress turned out to be something of a General Patton in
real life, too. ''Aren't potlucks supposed to be casual, bring-what-you-want
affairs?'' Ms. Leary asked. ''This woman was telling everyone what to bring in
the most minute detail. Like: 'You bring the feta and red bell pepper pasta.
I'll bring loose sea salt. Tell Peter to bring the pepper grinder. Will we have
enough candles? Who will bring the matches?'

''Not knowing who anyone was, at first I responded, 'Hey, sounds yummy, but
seriously, I don't think I belong in this email group.' But there were so many
emails back and forth that they didn't notice or acknowledge me.'' Finally, Ms.
Leary gave up and started chiming in with possible contributions: ''I'll bring
my famous banana bread!''

''After three days the actress realized what had happened and was like, 'Ann?'
'' Ms. Leary said.

At least Ms. Leary ended up on an endless email chain that comprised two of my
favorite things: celebrity and food. I share the same name and very similar
email with a woman whose life is a never-ending series of excited! emails! from
her personal shopper, Phi Mu Alpha sisters and knitting club. That was fine.

Then I started receiving emails from friends who had irrefutable proof that
President Obama was born in Kenya, learning socialism at the dusty feet of his
tribal overlords. One day I couldn't take it anymore, and hit ''Reply All'' with
my thoughts. The liberal pantywaist was removed from the thread.

So what are people to do when they have made a huge honking auto-fill error?
First, take heart: If you are using some email programs, like Gmail, you can
take back your email within the first 30 seconds of sending, according to a
Google spokeswoman. To enable this feature, follow the directions for the ''Undo
Send'' lab.

What if you recognize the error of your ways after, say, 31 seconds? I have had
those moments of slow-mo horror, where I simultaneously realize my mistake,
smash my keyboard and try to concoct the most plausible lie possible, while
hyperventilating at my desk.

''When email gets you into trouble, don't use email to try to get yourself out
of trouble,'' said Will Schwalbe, the Internet etiquette expert and author, with
David Shipley, of ''Send: Why People Email So Badly and How to Do It Better.''
''You can start the apology on email, but you need to continue it with a call, a
letter, flowers, wine, whatever it takes. The bigger the faux pas, the more
dramatic the gesture. Email apologies (even for email errors) are like email
thank yous: great for speed but ultimately not very impressive.''

Yet there can be an upside to the inadvertent blurt because, for all the
embarrassments, there are those moments of inadvertent connection; you may well
end up stumbling over not just an old enemy, but an old friend.

One of my closest buddies and I had an enormous fight several years ago. I
believed I was the wronged party, but in fact I wasn't. Yet I was too proud, and
too hurt, to make amends. A few weeks ago, in sending out a group email for a
get-together, I mistakenly included her address. She wrote back, saying that
although she knew she was not supposed to be on this chain, she was glad I
messed up, because she missed me.

After five years' absence, we're seeing each other next week. I kind of love my
auto-fill.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/fashion/the-perils-of-email-auto-fill.html

Nicola Albano, Dominic Rachiele

LENGTH: 210 words


Nicola Odessa Albano and Dr. Dominic Peter Rachiele were married Saturday at the
Church of St. Rita in Staten Island. Cardinal Orlando Beltran Quevedo, the Roman
Catholic archbishop of Cotabato, the Philippines, and an uncle of the bride,
performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Rachiele, 35, is a registered nurse for St. Luke's University Hospital
Network in Lehigh Valley, Pa. She has two bachelor's degrees, one in nursing
from Drexel University, and another in medical technology from the University of
Santo Tomas in Manila. Her father, Mario V. Albano of Todt Hill, Staten Island,
retired as an account officer for TIS Insurance Services in Knoxville, Tenn. Her
mother, Frances A. Albano of Los Angeles, is a nurse working for American
Caregiver at a senior living home there.

Dr. Rachiele, 44, is an oral and maxillofacial surgeon in Bethlehem, Pa. He
graduated from Bucknell and received a doctor of dental medicine degree from
Temple. The groom was a widower. He is the son of Nancy L. Rachiele and Thomas
J. Rachiele of Bethlehem. His mother, who is retired, worked in Morristown,
N.J., as a sales representative for Jack and Jill Ice Cream. His father owns a
barbershop in Bethlehem.

Ms. Albano and Dr. Rachiele were introduced in 2014 through CatholicMatch.com.

                              Late Edition - Final

Remembering Carl Apfel

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKINSON

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Style Desk; IN MEMORIAM; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 712 words


There is a moment in the film ''Iris'' -- the recent documentary made by Albert
Maysles -- when Iris and Carl Apfel are interviewed together in their New York
apartment. ''There was something about her that just got into me; it's always
there,'' says Carl of his wife of more than six decades. Iris cuts in, laughing:
''And I figured he was cool, and he was cuddly, and he cooked Chinese, so I
couldn't do any better.''

Carl Apfel passed away on Aug. 1, at the age of 100 -- only a few days away from
his 101st birthday. Apfel was, as Iris put it to T, ''a very generous man, and a
very funny man. He had a great, dry sense of humor and he was very kind to
everybody.''

''He was one of the most genteel men I've ever met,'' says the jewelry designer
Alexis Bittar, a close friend of the couple, who called Carl a ''surrogate
parent.'' ''I've never met a sweeter, more loving couple in my life than Carl
and Iris. I was so eager to spend time with them to learn how they navigated
their relationship.'' It was a sentiment echoed by the designer Duro Olowu,
another close friend. ''Carl was a wonderful man for many reasons: charming,
caring and funny,'' Olowu said in an e-mail. ''A real gentleman with an
inspiring and creative mind as well as exquisite taste and an impressive c.v.
But most of all his dedication to Iris is an example to us all of true and
unconditional love and mutual respect.''

The Apfels met in 1947, and married the following year. They began Old World
Weavers together in the 1950s: a small but prestigious company that sourced and
produced textiles from all over the world. As a result, Iris and Carl traveled
to far-flung places together -- to Turkey, Morocco, Lebanon -- Carl always with
a camera in hand. ''Carl and I, from the time we married, we did everything
together,'' Iris says. ''We worked together, we traveled together, we lived
together -- until just recently, I never went anywhere without him.''

Old World Weavers took off, and soon they had provided fabrics for the State
Department, the White House and the Metropolitan Museum of Art; they worked with
everyone from Greta Garbo to Jackie Kennedy. In 1992, Old World Weavers was
acquired by Stark Carpet -- but the Apfels continued to operate within the
larger company. In 2005, Iris became the subject of ''Rara Avis,'' an exhibition
at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute that celebrated her
eccentric style. It was a moment that changed her life, catapulting her into the
public eye and turning her, as she puts it now, into a ''geriatric startlet.''
Press requests and invitations poured in, and soon, Iris had collaborated with
brands such as MAC Cosmetics and the Home Shopping Network. Carl was enormously
proud. ''As friends have pointed out, some husbands would have been jealous, or
envious, or annoyed,'' Iris says. ''But he just loved it, he wallowed in it.''

Since then, Iris has become known as an international style icon -- and a symbol
for individuality -- but among friends, Carl was also known for his flair. ''He
was sharp as a tack, and he always looked like a dude,'' says Iris. He wore
round, plastic-framed glasses and, when they ran Old World Weavers, often had
patterned upholsteries turned into pants. ''Somebody would say to him, 'Oh, what
beautiful trousers, where did you get those?''' Iris remembers. ''And he would
say, 'I just shot my couch.'''

''He knows how to have fun with life,'' says Bittar. ''He understands the
seriousness of everything, but he had come to the conclusion that it's better to
be lighthearted in your perspective of life than get heavy.''

On one hand, Carl also wore a large, gold Egyptian ring inscribed with the
phrase ''Where Is the House of Thy Father?'' He never went without it --
primarily because he couldn't get it off. Iris purchased the ring for him on an
antiquing jag in Dublin in the 1950s (a veteran bargainer, she convinced an
antiquarian to sell it off his own finger, even though it was not for sale); but
shortly after putting it on, Carl found he couldn't remove it. So he wore the
ring for decades, enduring changes of season and surgeries. Two days before he
died, the ring finally fell off.


This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.




URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/26/t-magazine/carl-apfel-in-memoriam.html

on a trip to Southern Italy in the late 1970s
and at an event in 2008. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY BRUCE WEBER
MAGNOLIA PICTURES
 BILLY FARRELL/PATRICK McMULLAN)

In Bali, a Riverfront Resort

BYLINE: By ELAINE GLUSAC

SECTION: Section TR; Column 0; Travel Desk; IN TRANSIT; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 588 words


Our Friday morning parks and recreation news digest, with deals, tips and
anything else that travelers may want to know.

SHARING ECONOMY EXPANDS AMONG R.V. USERS

Owners of an underused recreational vehicle, meet potential renters. That's the
premise of the new R.V.-sharing website Outdoorsy.co, which was introduced
nationally Thursday. Like Airbnb for road trippers, the site allows vehicle
owners to list their R.V., allowing travelers to search for them, subsequently
negotiate terms and afterward review and rate them. At launch, the site listed
2,300 RVs for rent. The company expects to reach 5,000 by year end, and 25,000
in the first year, as it says it is enlisting 50 to 75 new entries per day.
Outdoorsy isn't the first R.V. sharing site; competitors include RVShare.com.
But the newcomer says it offers at least one unique selling point: It allows
owners and renters to purchase liability insurance for coverage up to $1
million. The average six-night rental at Outdoorsy costs $1,961. Fully loaded
R.V.s with extras like linens, bikes and barbecues average $2,400 for the same
period.

ROAD TRIP NARRATION COMES TO TWO NATIONAL PARKS

If you've ever enjoyed a road trip, but wondered what exactly you were looking
at, now there's an app for that. The Just Ahead smartphone app acts as a
GPS-triggered audio guide, and has just released new guides to Yellowstone and
Grand Teton National Parks. In Yellowstone, the tour covers 600 stories related
to geysers, wildlife and folklore. The Grand Teton guide highlights natural
features like Jackson Lake and Teton Glacier and covers the human history of the
area from American Indians to cattle ranchers and early mountaineers. Both
provide day-trip suggestions and work without Internet connectivity as an audio
guidebook. With web access, the program's GPS tracking offers stories and maps
related to the user's location. The app is available for both iPhone and Android
platforms and guides cost $7.99 to $9.99 each.

AN INTERNMENT CAMP RECLAIMS A PIECE OF ITS PAST

A World War II confinement site for Japanese-Americans during the war, Heart
Mountain WWII Interpretive Center near Cody, Wyo., will observe its annual
pilgrimage event this year with the return of an original barrack. The
pilgrimage, taking place today and Saturday, invites former prisoners and their
families as well as the general public back to the site for panel discussions,
storytelling and memorial ceremonies. The 20-by-120-foot barrack was used
between August 1942 and November 1945 when some 14,000 Japanese-Americans were
forced into the camp. It was later moved 80 miles away and used as a university
research facility. The barrack and the only remaining root cellar in a camp that
once grew 2,500 tons of produce annually to sustain itself will be dedicated
this weekend and open thereafter to visitors to the National Historic Landmark.

A NEW PARK IN SYDNEY

Adding to the natural beauty of Sydney's waterfront, the new Barangaroo Reserve
opens Saturday, reclaiming 14 formerly industrial acres once devoted to storing
shipping containers. The now-contoured headland edged in sandstone was inspired
by the pre-colonial landscape and features newly planted trees and brush that
represent the native Australian bush. Adjacent to the Central Business District,
the new park offers Wulugul Walk, a shoreside promenade, as well as a central
gathering area that can accommodate up to 5,500 people.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/21/travel/parks-and-recreation-news-rv-sharing-we
bsite-launches-and-more.html

Hotels: Soho House Goes Rural

BYLINE: By ELAINE GLUSAC

SECTION: Section TR; Column 0; Travel Desk; IN TRANSIT; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 694 words


Our Wednesday morning hotel and cruise digest, with deals, tips and anything
else that travelers may want to know.

IN BALI, A RIVERFRONT RESORT

The central Bali town of Ubud has long attracted wellness seekers, and its
newest luxury resort, Mandapa, a Ritz-Carlton Reserve, makes its spa, nutrition
and healing therapies central appeals. Opening Sept. 5, the resort features 35
suites and 25 villas, the latter with open-air passages between bedroom and
living areas, arranged around a terraced rice field on the Ayung River. The
eight-treatment-room spa features a riverfront yoga studio and classes ranging
from art therapy and circuit training in the jungle to juicing and vegan
cooking. Four restaurants and lounges will feature detoxifying culinary options
as well as more indulgent ones, and much of the produce is sourced from an
on-site garden. Rounding out its holistic approach, Mandapa welcomes children
too; the resort's Green Camp kid's program focuses on environmental learning and
Balinese culture. Rooms from $570.

NEW FAMILY CRUISES FROM TAUCK

Lacking the bells, whistles and water parks of oceangoing vessels, river cruise
ships tend to attract more adult travelers, though the tour operator Tauck plans
to double its family river cruise departures in the next two years. It currently
offers 10 family-focused itineraries on Europe's Danube, Rhine and Rhone Rivers
in 2016 and will expand to 20 family trips in 2017 on those and one more
to-be-determined waterway. The new route is in the planning phase, but the
company says it designs its trips with children in mind, pointing to current
excursions that include scavenger hunts in the Louvre Museum in Paris; medieval
games in Bratislava, Slovakia; guided riverside cycling trips in Austria; and
cooking classes of the gooey variety involving chocolate, marzipan and fondue.
The 2016 trips start at $3,690 per person on the eight-day Blue Danube: Family
Riverboat Adventure cruise.

LABOR DAY DISCOUNTS IN ORLANDO

With most families occupied by back-to-school preparations, Labor Day weekend is
a relatively low-season holiday for the theme parks and resorts of Orlando. Many
of the latter are offering discounts up to 40 percent off rooms compared with
holidays like July 4. Among examples, Cabana Bay at Universal Orlando Resort is
offering rooms from $116 per night through Sept. 6, and the Hyatt Regency Grand
Cypress is offering the fourth night free between Aug. 24 and Dec. 23 on rooms
starting at $159 per night. Beginning Aug. 24 and throughout September, visitors
can take advantage of more deals, this time on food, during Orlando's inaugural
Magical Dining Month, featuring $33 prix fixe dinners at a range of restaurants.

SOHO HOUSE GOES RURAL

The collection of stylish Soho Houses, private clubs with rooms to rent offering
entrée to nonmembers, moves to green acres with the recent August opening of
Soho Farmhouse. The London-based company's 15th  location resides on 100 acres
in Oxfordshire, about 80 miles northwest of London. Its 40 units range from a
one-bedroom cottage to a seven-bedroom house, and resort amenities include a
swimming pool, two tennis courts with two more grass courts to come next spring,
a stable with horseback riding, and a full-service spa. Soho Houses are
well-known for their culinary aspects, and the country version continues the
tradition with a restaurant that includes its own kitchen garden and smokehouse,
and food trucks that guests can call around the clock. Accommodations from £225
($340).

NEW EUROPEAN CRUISES FROM CUNARD

Whether you want a quick weeklong cruise or a deeper in-depth port stay, Cunard
aims to satisfy with new 2016 European itineraries aboard its 2,000-passenger
Queen Victoria. Announced this month, new seven-night cruises include sailing in
and around Norway's fjords and exploring the coast of Spain and Portugal. For
those with more time, many of the new nine-to-12-day itineraries in the
Mediterranean include overnight stays in Venice and Istanbul. Seven-day cruises
start at $1,198 per person, double occupancy.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.

Paid Notice: Deaths STROUD, MARION BOULTON

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 273 words


STROUD--Marion Boulton. The Board of Trustees, Artist Advisory Committee and
Staff of the Fabric Workshop and Museum (FWM) deeply mourn the loss of our
visionary founder, leader and long-time friend, Marion (Kippy) Boulton Stroud.

A supporter of the arts and artists, curator, author and arts administrator,
Kippy pioneered the practice of direct support to artists through her unique
residency program at the Fabric Workshop and Museum, founded in Philadelphia in
1977. Her deep and abiding encouragement of artists to advance the boundaries of
their practice by offering them opportunities to experiment in a vast range of
media resulted in the FWM long record of groundbreaking residencies and
exhibitions and the Museum's important collection of 20th and 21st century art.
The unique works of art created at FWM are shown with regularity throughout the
United States and the world in major museums and cultural venues. Kippy was
deeply and passionately devoted to artists and the artistic community and
provided her unstinting support. She believed in the power of experimentation
and creativity and fostered access to arts for everyone. Kippy broke down
barriers--within social structures and within the process of art making. We
extend our deepest sympathy to Kippy's family of cousins-- Rosengartens, Sims
and Strouds--and to her extended family of artists and arts professionals who
have been so deeply inspired by her generous and giving spirit. Katherine
Sokolnikoff, President of the Board Stewart Cades, First Vice President Ann
Loftus, Second Vice President of the Board John Ravenal, Chairman of the Artist
Advisory Committee 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths STROUD, MARION BOULTON

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 162 words


STROUD--Marion Boulton. It is with great sadness that The International Council
of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the sudden passing of Marion (Kippy)
Boulton Stroud. Kippy, of Philadelphia, Palm Beach, Florida, and Mount Desert
Island in Maine, was a member of the International Council since 1995.
Enormously energetic, creative, generous, and hardworking, she was a
multifaceted talent who was beloved by her many friends, including artists and
colleagues from around the world. Among her passions were The Fabric Workshop
and Museum in Philadelphia, which she founded and where she remained artistic
director until her death; the Acadia Summer Arts Program on Mount Desert Island;
the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where she was a trustee; ArtTable; and the
American Crafts Council. Kippy will be sorely missed. Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo
Carole Lauder, President Emerita Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President The
International Council of The Museum of Modern Art 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths RICHARD, HAROLD VAN BUREN

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 174 words


RICHARD--Harold Van Buren, aged 100, died peacefully in York Harbor, ME on
August 27th, 2015. Raised in New York City, Van attended St. Paul's School in
Concord, NH and graduated from Princeton University, class of 1936. After
serving in World War II as a Destroyer Escort Skipper in the Pacific, he lived
in Brookville, NY and headed C.B. Richard & Co., retiring to Vero Beach, FL in
1983. A lifelong philanthropist, he was an avid golfer, bridge player and world
traveler. A kind and thoughtful man with a very positive approach to life, his
generosity and spirit will never be forgotten by his family and many friends.
Predeceased by his son Peter and his wife of 65 years Jane, he is survived by
his loving family; daughter Phyllis Fritts (Guy), daughter-in-law, Virginia
Richard and five grandchildren; James Fritts (Diana), Garret Fritts, William Z.
Richard (Erica), Travis Richard, Cecily Beach (Charles) and six
great-grandchildren. A Celebration of his life will be held this fall in Vero
Beach, FL. Visit www. lucaseatonfuneralhome.com 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths MCKEIGE, BRUCE D.

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 157 words


McKEIGE--Bruce D.,85, of Stuart, FL, and Montauk, NY passed away August 15, 2015
in Stuart. Born June 6, 1930, in Port Washington, NY, he graduated from Union
College and served as an officer aboard a naval minesweeper. He was happily
married to Sarah Beekman from 1953 until her death in 2005. Bruce founded his
successful Mortgage and Financial Securities firm, McKeige & Co., in Port
Washington in 1971. He was a great yachtsman, mariner, fisherman, and hunter,
and champion sailor. He is survived by his two children: Douglas McKeige of
Mamaroneck, NY, and Cornelia McKeige Localio of Tarrytown, NY; their spouses
Marie and Craig; grandchildren Natalie, Olivia, Ian, Will and Charlotte; and his
loving partner, Lenice Hirschberger. A memorial service will take place Friday,
September 11, 6pm at American Yacht Club, Milton Pt., Rye, NY. In lieu of
flowers, donations to Save the Sound, 545 Tompkins Ave., 3rd Floor, Mamaroneck,
NY 10543. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths MCCORMACK, SISTER UNA

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 145 words


McCORMACK--Sister Una, O.P. - The Board of Directors and staff of Catholic
Guardian Services wish to express their deep sorrow at the passing of Sister Una
McCormack, O.P., former and longtime executive director of Catholic Home Bureau,
one of our predecessor agencies. Sister Una devoted her ministry to the care of
children, women, and families in need. Countless people were touched by her
compassionate service. She began as a social worker aiding orphaned, abandoned
and abused children and went on to head two major foster care agencies: Cardinal
McCloskey Children & Family Services and Catholic Home Bureau. In the
mid-1980's, she oversaw development of Incarnation Children's Center, believed
to be the nation's first residence for babies and young children with AIDS. She
will be greatly missed. Rory Kelleher Chair of the Board Craig Longley Executive
Director 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths MARSHALL, MR

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 117 words


MARSHALL--Mr. Edward, of Lawrence, NY and Boca Raton, FL died peacefully on
Sunday, August 23rd, at his home in Lawrence, one month shy of his 88th
birthday. He attended City College and was drafted into the United States Army
Air Force where he served from 1945-1946. Through the GI bill, he attended
Fordham Law School graduating in 1950. Mr. Marshall was an attorney and avid
golfer, but most of all he was a devout family man. He is survived by his wife
of 20 years, Maxine Goldberg Marshall; his children Craig (wife Nancy), Richard
(wife Jaimee); his grandchildren, Neal, Danny, Katie and Hannah; and his
stepchildren Douglas, Laura, Robert and Lisa and their respective spouses and
children. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths LURIE, ABRAHAM

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 104 words


LURIE--Abraham, on August 25, 2015 at the age of 97. Beloved husband of the late
Nettie, loving father of Susan (Don) and Debra (George). Cherished grandfather
of Raphael and Anna. Devoted partner of Anita Gurian. A person of keen
intellect, commitment to social change and social justice, Abe was one of the
great innovators in social work. His health and mental health program models
continue to be used globally. He embodied the best in practice, research,
management and program innovation. His work will be carried on by the many
people he taught, mentored and inspired and by his writings which number in the
hundreds. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths KNIGHT, FRANCES "PEG" F

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 207 words


KNIGHT--Frances "Peg" F. (nee Floyd) 95, of Saddle River passed away on August
27, 2015. Born in Savannah, GA she has lived in Saddle River since 1961. A
member of St. Bartholomew's Church in Ho Ho Kus, Peg was an active volunteer for
The Red Cross, the Forum School of Waldwick and The Junior League of Bergen
County. Peg was a true enthusiast and benefactor of Hackensack University
Medical Center, The New York Philharmonic and The Metropolitan Opera. She had a
passion for traveling and enjoyed every corner of the world. Beloved wife of the
late William T. Knight, III (1997). Devoted mother of Rex Knight and his wife
Nancy of Westchester, NY. Loving grandmother of Jennifer, Douglas and Kristen.
The family will receive family and friends on Sunday from 3-7pm at Vander Plaat-
Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes. Funeral
Services Monday 11am at St. Bartholomew's Church, Ho Ho Kus. Interment St.
Bonaventure Cemetery, Savannah, GA. The family request donations in memory of
Frances to the Heart and Vascular Hospital at the Hackensack University Medical
Center Foundation, 361 Essex Street, Suite 301, Hackensack, NJ 07601. For
further information please visit www.vpmemorial.com or call (201) 891-4770. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths KEHOE, ELIZABETH FOULK

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 120 words


KEHOE--Elizabeth Foulk, died peacefully at her residence in Greenville, RI this
past Tuesday. She was 92. Ms. Kehoe was born in Beijing, China and grew up in
Manhasset, NY. She graduated from Vassar College in the class of 1944, and began
a career in New York as a public relations staff writer for NBC, where she met
and later married David Drew Zingg. In the 1960s she worked at Irvington House
at NYU Medical Center and then at the Metropolitan Opera National Council.
Throughout her life she was passionate about music, from cabaret to Broadway and
the opera. After her retirement, she and her second husband, Richard G. Kehoe,
moved to Lyme, and Chester, CT. She is survived by three sons and five
grandchildren. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths KAPLAN, LLOYD ARTHUR

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 237 words


KAPLAN--Lloyd Arthur, Publicist, writer and strategist, who counseled
government, business and non-profit leaders over a career that spanned five
decades, died on Thursday of complications from amyloidosis. He was 80, although
many people will find that hard to believe.

He worked diligently and effectively to the end of his life. He is survived by
his wife of 25 years and business partner, Lisa Linden, his children Zachary and
Polly Kaplan, daughter-in-law Daphne Klein, and grandchildren Tiger and Atticus
Kaplan and Olivia Dylewski. Born to Sarah (Simon) and Moses Kaplan, Lloyd grew
up in the Bronx. He received a BA from NYU (1955) and MFA from Yale University
(1958). He served as Director of Public Affairs, New York City Planning
Commission (1961-1975), Special Assistant to Mayor Abraham Beame and Chief of
Staff to First Deputy Mayor John Zuccotti (1975-78), Deputy New York State
Housing Commissioner (1978-81), Executive Vice President at Rubenstein
Associates (1981-1996), and Chairman of LAK Public Relations (1996-2015). He
loved classical music, theater, literature, art and antiques, Cape Cod, the
North Fork, good wine, and life. Interment will be private. A Memorial Service
will be held on Friday, October 2nd, at Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83rd
Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Citymeals-on-Wheels, or
Alzheimers Association of New York City would be appreciated. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths KANTOR, HOWARD M.D

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 342 words


KANTOR--Howard M.D. Howard Lionel Kantor M.D., passed away peacefully on August
13, 2015 surrounded by three generations of his loving family. He was 90. He was
an accomplished doctor, athlete, world traveler and lover of the arts. He is
survived by Gloria, his devoted and loving wife of 68 years; by his three
children, Lauren, Karen and Jonathan; and by seven grandchildren, Rachel, Sara,
Julia, David, Danielle, Allison and Benjamin.

Born in Kansas City, MO on October 17, 1924, he was one of three children. He
grew up in Tulsa, Oklahoma, where he was an Eagle Scout and an exceptional
student; he skipped two grades in school and graduated high school at the age of
15. He received a prestigious military scholarship to attend college at Rutgers
University and then medical school at Columbia University in New York. After
receiving his medical degree, he went on to become a pediatrician. He served in
the military first as a private in the Army during the Second World War and then
as a captain in the Air Force during the Korean War. Following his military
service, Kantor entered private practice initially as a pediatrician in Syosset,
NY, subsequently focusing solely on allergy-immunology in Huntington, NY. He
served as the President of the Nassau Suffolk Allergy Society of New York in
1985-87. A talented practitioner, he had a loyal patient following that included
multiple generations of families. With extraordinary dedication and enthusiasm,
he continued his medical practice until the end of his life. He loved nature and
the outdoors and spent many vacations throughout his life with his extended
family hiking and skiing in the Rocky Mountains. He was an exceptional athlete
and was especially accomplished in tennis. He and his wife, during their long
and loving marriage, together traveled to 60 countries. He was a sculptor, a
painter, an accomplished gardener, and loved to dance. We remember him for his
commitment to his profession, his loving devotion to his family and friends, and
his ability to live life to the fullest. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths JENNINGS, RICHARD

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 579 words


JENNINGS--Richard. Richard Townsley Jennings, a remarkable and beloved man, died
unexpectedly from complications due to a medical procedure on August 13. Born in
New York City in 1933, he grew up in a close-knit, hard-working family. His
mother, Cora and father, Alfred, were intelligent people of character who raised
two sons, Richard and his older brother, Donald, and their niece, Virginia,
raised as Richard's sister. By the time he was 15-years-old, he lost both his
brother and father, and went on two years later, to put himself through college
at Columbia University where he majored in music and business.

He was the first in his family to attend college. A fine and gifted pianist,
upon graduating from Columbia, Richard was a soldier in the Korean War where he
entertained the troops. This ability to reduce the suffering of others, and to
offer the music he so loved, brought him much joy. When he returned, he tried
with his characteristic steady determination to become a professional jazz
pianist and composer, and made one record called, "He Loves Me." Shortly
thereafter, he met Regina, a young Peruvian beauty and fellow lover of music and
literature. A person of unshakeable character, Richard began writing jingles to
provide for his bride and their beloved son, Christopher, born shortly after
they married in New York City. He went on to have a 40- year distinguished
career as an advertising executive, where he implemented the "Bob, for Texaco,
Hope" commercials, wrapping up at Saatchi & Saatchi. He was a first class Ad man
with the temperament of a gentle and gifted introvert. When it came to being a
parent, Richard was ahead of his time. In addition to providing for his family's
basic needs, he thoroughly enjoyed cooking for them, reading to his kids,
singing with them and helping them get ready for school. He spent countless
hours teaching his son what it meant to be an honorable man, how to work
diligently to achieve goals, how to care for others even and especially when
great sacrifice was required, and loved spending time with him going to see
every New York sports team, then briskly walking to Grand Central Station,
sometimes whistling to a favorite Frank Sinatra tune on the way home. His
daughter Pilar, born four years after Christopher, quickly developed a boundless
love for him. They were the shy, bookish ones in the family, with a shared and
passionate love of learning. Throughout her childhood, she watched him with awe
as he finished The New York Times crossword puzzle in the time it took her to
tie her shoes. He often complained, with his marvelously dry sense of humor,
that the puzzle was too easy that day, then affectionately tap her on the head
with the rolled up paper. When she learned the word "erudite," she realized that
it was the perfect way to describe her father, a history buff, politico, and
lover of the written word. It is with immense sadness, endless gratitude and
love, that we say goodbye. Richard was a profoundly devoted father, grandfather
to Carley, Samantha, and Mattie, a caring friend, a person of true character,
intellect, culture, and consummate joyful foodie. A truly good and loving man.
In lieu of flowers, please send donations to support students who are first in
their family to attend college at Columbia University's School of General
Studies. Mailing address: Office of the Dean, School of General Studies, 612
Lewisohn Hall MC4103, Columbia University, New York, NY 10027. 1/3

URL:

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Paid Death Notice

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 82 words


GLASER--Gerry "The Glaze," died peacefully at his home in New York City on
August 24th surrounded by his loving family. He is survived by his wife, Mary
Cagney, son Matthew Glaser, daughter Claudia Glaser-Mussen, son-in-law Jim,
step-sons Frank Vitiello and Jamie Vitiello, daugh- ters-in-law Lara and Juli,
grandchildren Jacob, Mikayla, Kai, Francesca, and Fiona and his brother Milton.
There will be a memorial celebration on Sunday, November 1, 2015. Please contact
the family for details. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths FERRITER, ROGER

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 161 words


FERRITER--Roger, of Larchmont, NY, passed away on August 28, 2015. He was 82.
Born in Cranston, RI on September 6, 1932 to George and Olive Ferriter, Roger
proudly served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Marine Corp, played minor league
baseball and became a world renowned graphic designer, best known as the creator
of L'eggs. Roger is survived by his beloved wife Phyllis, loving children,
Eugene Ferriter (Maureen), Julianna Bruce (Daniel) and Ken Ferriter (Kathy),
step-son Matthew, cherished grandchildren, Elliot, Brianna, Charlotte, Drake and
Bella, he was predeceased by his dear brothers Herb, Ted and Chick Ferriter. To
honor Roger's life, family and friends will gather on Monday from 4-8pm at Coxe
& Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck 914-698-5968.
Funeral Mass 11am Tuesday at St. Augustine's R.C. Church, followed by interment
at Greenwood Union Cemetery. For more information or to place an online
condolence, www.coxeandgraziano.com 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths FEINSTEIN, MITCHELL

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 93 words


FEINSTEIN--Mitchell, devoted husband and best friend to wife Lori Hoberman,
constant companion, coach and confidante to son Sammy, source of unflagging love
and goodness to his parents, his sister and his mother-in-law, and the glue that
held so much together with his characteristic wisdom and modesty. We are hurting
for you and for the magnitude of the family's loss. Our condolences, fortitude,
enduring friendship and love go out to you to help you through this most
difficult period. Jerry & Ruthie Kestenbaum, Zach & Rina, TJ & Erica, Joe &
Jesse. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths CORTESI, HENRY BENNING

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 122 words


CORTESI--Henry Benning, died August 22nd at his home in Manhattan after a long
illness. Born in New York on August 5th 1936, he was a graduate of Milton
Academy, Harvard College, and the University of Pennsylvania law school. For
most of his career he practiced law at Webster & Sheffield. He was a prodigious
reader of contemporary literature and a lifelong collector of paintings. In 1990
he married Nan Rosenthal, a curator of 20th century art, who predeceased him in
2014. He is survived by his sister, Katharine Cortesi Armstrong, his brothers
Roger Spencer Cortesi and Alexander Cochrane Cortesi, and eight nieces and
nephews. A man of subversive wit and precise personal style, he will be missed.
Services will be private. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths BUCKSBAUM, MELVA

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 64 words


BUCKSBAUM--Melva. The entire staff of Christie's America is saddened by the
death of our friend and Advisory Board member Melva Bucksbaum. Her charm,
counsel and grace will be much missed within our firm and in the wider Art World
community. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Raymond Learsy and to
her entire family. Marc Porter, Chairman; Stephen Lash, Chairman Emeritus 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths APFEL, CARL

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 71 words


APFEL--Carl. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art note with
sadness the passing of Carl Apfel, a charming and debonair friend for whom --
along with his wife Iris -- a gallery in the Anna Wintour Costume Center is
named. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Iris. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman
Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Daniel Weiss, President Harold Koda,
Curator in Charge, The Costume Institute 1/3
